Scott Murray, ''Australia on the Small Screen 1970-1995'', Oxford Uni Press, 1996 p11 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0381901/ ''Banduk''] at [[IMDB]] [[Category:Australian television films]] [[Category:Australian films]] {{Australia-tv-film-stub}}

{{Bayesian statistics}} '''Bayesian efficiency''' is an analog of [[Pareto efficiency]] for situations in which there is [[incomplete information]].<ref name="implementation">Palfrey, Thomas R.; Srivastava, Sanjay; Postlewaite, A. (1993) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=lZTls-JJSxgC&pg=PA13 Bayesian Implementation.]'' Pg. 13-14. {{ISBN|3-7186-5314-1}}</ref> Under Pareto efficiency, an allocation of a resource is Pareto efficient if there is no other allocation of that resource that makes no one worse off while making some agents strictly better off.<ref name="implementation"/> A limitation with the concept of Pareto efficiency is that it assumes that knowledge about other market participants is available to all participants, in that every player knows the payoffs and strategies available to other players so as to have complete information.<ref name="implementation"/> Often, the players have types that are hidden from the other player.<ref name="implementation"/>
==Overview== The lack of complete information raises a question of when the efficiency calculation should be made.<ref name="implementation"/> Should the efficiency check be made at the [[ex ante]] stage before the agent sees their types, at the interim stage after the agent sees their types, or at the [[ex post]] stage where the agent will have complete information about their types? Another issue is incentive.<ref name="implementation"/> If a resource allocation rule is efficient but there is no incentive to abide by that rule or accept that rule, then the [[revelation principle]] asserts that there is no mechanism by which this allocation rule can be realized.<ref name="implementation"/>
Bayesian efficiency overcomes problems of the [[Pareto efficiency]] by accounting for incomplete information, by addressing the timing of the evaluation (ex ante efficient, interim efficient, or ex post efficient), and by adding an incentive qualifier so that the allocation rule is incentive compatible.<ref name="implementation"/><ref>Baltagi, Badi Hani. (2001) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=qjBF3Z3xcWYC&printsec=frontcover A Companion to Theoretical Econometrics.]'' Blackwell Publishing. {{ISBN|1-4051-0676-X}}</ref>
Bayesian efficiency separately defines three types of efficiency: ex ante, interim, and ex post. For an allocation rule <math>x:T\to A</math>:
''Ex ante efficiency'': <math>x</math> is incentive compatible, and there exists no incentive compatible allocation rule <math>y:T\to A</math> that
:<math>\int u^i(y(t),t)dG^i(t) \geq \int u^i(x(t),t)dG^i(t)</math>
for all <math>i</math>, with strict inequality for some <math>i</math>.
''Interim efficiency'': <math>x</math> is incentive compatible, and there exists no incentive compatible allocation rule <math>y:T\to A</math> that
:<math>\int U^i(y(t),t)dG^i(t_{-i}|t_i) \geq \int U^i(x(t),t)dG^i(t_{-i}|t_i)</math>
for all <math>i</math> and <math>t_i</math>, with strict inequality for some <math>i</math> and <math>t_i</math>.
''Ex post efficiency'': <math>x</math> is incentive compatible, and there exists no incentive compatible allocation rule <math>y:T\to A</math> that
:<math>U^i(y(t),t) \geq U^i(x(t),t)</math>
for all <math>i</math>, with strict inequality for some <math>i</math>.
Here, <math>G^i</math> are beliefs, <math>U^i</math> are utility functions, and <math>i</math> are agents. An ex ante allocation is always interim and ex post efficient, and an interim efficient allocation is always ex post efficient.<ref name="implementation"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{game theory}}
[[Category:Bayesian statistics]] [[Category:Pareto efficiency]] [[Category:Game theory]] [[Category:Law and economics]] [[Category:Mathematical optimization]] [[Category:Optimal decisions]] [[Category:Electoral system criteria]] [[Category:Welfare economics]]

{{advert|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox amusement park |name = Bonbon-land |image = [[File:Bonbonland logo.png|Bonbon-land logo]] |location = [[Holme Olstrup]], [[Denmark]] |coordinates = {{Coord|55|15|38|N|11|51|50|E|type:landmark_region:DK|display=inline,title}} |opening_date = 1992 |season = April 1. - October 24. |rides = 65 |owner = [[Parques Reunidos]] |homepage = http://www.bonbonland.dk }} '''BonBon-Land''' is a Danish [[amusement park]] located in [[Holme Olstrup]] in the South of [[Zealand]], about 100km from [[Copenhagen]]. This 34-acre park attracts about 450.000 each season. ==History== The history of theme park BonBon-land can be dated back to when the Danish sweets boiler Michael Spangsberg got an idea to produce wacky candy with such funny names as 'mågeklatter', 'hundeprutter' and 'tissebleer'.
From early on the candy became very popular, and children wanted to visit the factory in Holme Olstrup (a small Danish town in the countryside) to see how the cheeky and delicious pieces of candy were made. However, the production of the candy had to fulfil some very strict regulations concerning hygiene, so the factory couldn´t continue to offer visiting tours. As a result, Michael Spangsberg came up with yet another good idea - to open a small Bonbon-land.
In 1992, the theme park opened with a mini candy factory, a cinema, a shop and four small boats, shaped like a duck in a small pond. The park was an immediate success with children and over the years many rides and attractions have been added making, despite with adult-oriented contents and toilet humor throughout, Bonbon-Land one of Denmark´s most popular children´s parks (in 2008 it was the eight most popular tourist attraction in Denmark).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitdenmark.com/danmark/da-dk/menu/turist/oplevelser/attraktioner/sightseeing/tophalvtreds.htm|title=Top 50 most visited attractions 2008|accessdate=27 May 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415234330/http://visitdenmark.com/danmark/da-dk/menu/turist/oplevelser/attraktioner/sightseeing/tophalvtreds.htm|archivedate=2009-04-15|deadurl=yes|date=15 April 2009}} ''VisitDanmark's homepage''</ref> In 2007, the Spanish-based entertainment company Parques Reunidos purchased the park.
In total, Parques Reunidos owns 67 theme parks around the world.<ref>[http://www.parquesreunidos.com/ Owners of Bonbon Land] ''Parques Reunidos homepage'' Retrieved 27 May 2010.</ref>
From the beginning BonBon-land has focused on experiences that the whole family could enjoy. Today, Bonbon-land has over 60 different attractions and numerous activities on offer. Among the most popular rides in the park are the 4 roller coasters and the 2 water rides. There are also a number of playgrounds and a pirate track that visitors can try out.
Up until 1998, BonBon-land had expanded its park to cover an area of 85.000 m² (21 acres). When the Beaver-Rafting course was finished in 1998, it was suddenly more than 110.000 m² (27 acres). Then in 2003, in connection with the opening of ’Vildsvinet’, the park expanded yet again to cover roughly 130.000 m² (32 acres), which is now its current size.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonbonland.dk/textpage.aspx?pid=78|title=BonBon-Lands History|accessdate=27 May 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028150750/http://www.bonbonland.dk/textpage.aspx?pid=78#|archivedate=2010-10-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The most expensive amusements are the rafting course with a price of 32 million DKK, 'Vildsvinet' from 2003, with an estimated price of 25 million DKK as well as 'Hankatten' that had a price of 20 million DKK. New amusements in 2010 are 'Svend Svingarm' and a brand new 4D cinema.
In 2012 it was ranked as one of the weirdest parks by ''Time''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2106937_2106938_2106942,00.html|author=Samantha Grossman|title=Top 10 Weirdest Theme Parks - BonBon Land|work=Time|date=16 February 2012|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref>
==Roller Coasters== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Ride Name !! Type !! Opened in !! Manufacturer !! Additional Information |- |[[Hundeprutterutchebane]] (The Farting Dog Switchback)||steel sit down||1993||[[Zierer]]||Reaches a speed of 18 mph (30km) on a 420 ft long track (128m) and a height of 15 ft (4,5m); height limit none / 1,1m alone. Force One model, train 2x10. |- |[[Vild-Svinet]] (The Wild Boar)||steel sit down||2003||[[Gerstlauer]]||Reaches a speed of 45 mph (73km) on a 1404 ft long track (428m) and a height of 72 ft (22m); height 1,25m. Euro Fighter model 500/8, the initial drop is at an angle of 97°. |- |Hankatten (Tom Cat)||steel sit down spinning wild mouse||2007||Gerstlauer||Reaches a speed of 34 mph (55km) on a 1303 ft long track (397m) and a height of 53 ft (16m); height limit 1,1m. Spinning Coaster model 380/4, car 2+2. |- |Viktor Vandorm (Victor The Water Worm)||steel sit down||2009||Zierer||Reaches a speed of 33 mph (53km) on a 2471 ft long track (750m) and a height of 46 ft (14m); height limit 1m. Tivoli Custom model, train 2x20. |- |} ===Water Rides=== *'''Beaver Rafting''' - river rapids ride that opened in 1998. This 6-passenger raft ride is on a scenic 560m long course. [[Intamin]]. *'''The Water Rat''' - log flume ride that opened in 1995. A 220m long ride that features 2 drops on the way. CB Design. ===Other Rides=== *'''The Albatross''' - diskO that was opened in 2004; height limit 1,1m. [[Zamperla]]. *'''The Cobra Tower''' - drop tower that opened in 2001; height limit 1,2m. [[Fabbri Group|Fabbri]]. *'''The Crow Trees''' - hoist yourself up tower that opened in 2006; height limit 1,2m. Premier Rides. *'''Dillen (Mania)''' - air swing ride that opened in 1999; height limit none / 1,25m alone. Huss. *'''4D Film''' - theatre opened in 2010, currently showing The Little Prince. *'''Hestorado''' - stationary 5D interactive laser shoot out that opened in 2011; height limit 1,1m. [[Alterface]]. *'''Klitorskin (The Cod) ''' - swinging ship that opened in 2002; height limit 1,1m. *'''The Octopus''' - octopus ride. *'''Paradise''' - walkthrough Candy Store that opened in 1992. *'''Søløven (The Sea Lion)''' - dark boat ride that opened in 2005. CB Design. *'''Svend The Swinging Arm''' - giant swing that opened in 2009; height limit 1,4m. [[Zamperla]]. *'''The Tortoise''' - wave swinger that opened in 1994. Zierer. *'''The Worm''' - roundabout ride.
===Kiddie Rides=== *'''The Dragon''' - himalaya style ride. *'''Fantasy World''' - walkthrough with fantasy-like scenes and kiddie play area that opened in 2009. *'''Flying Insects''' - air spinner for kids. *'''Hot Wheels''' - kids can operate cars, mini trucks, excavators (opened in 2006). *'''Hugo the Happy Horse''' - on track horse ride. *'''Play Areas''' - the park has a number of play areas with various activities for kids. *'''The Seagull''' - children´s monorail. *'''The Shrimp''' - dinghy ride. *'''Trampolines''' - trampolines. *'''Walk the Plank''' - challenge course. *'''The Wet Dolphin''' - water play ground that opened in 2007.
===Other=== The park has Arcade Games, various Test-Your-Skill Games and a Kiddie Show.
==Picture Gallery== <gallery> File:BonBon-Lands udgang.jpg|Entrance to the park File:Vildsvinet (BonBon-Land).jpg|Vildsvinet ride File:BonBon-Lands forlystelse Alba-Tossen.jpg|Albatros ride File:BonBon-Lands biograf BON-BIO 4D.jpg|4D Cinema </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|BonBon-Land}} *[http://www.bonbonland.dk BonBon-Land's homepage]
{{Parques Reunidos}}

{{distinguish|text=the [[British Amateur Press Association]], founded 1890}} The '''British Amateur Press Association''' was an [[amateur press association]] created by comics fans in late 1977, following a proposal from Phil Greenaway in the letter pages of the [[comics]] [[fanzine]] ''Bemusing''; the first mailing (under the name ''PAPA'', the first initial standing for "Prime") was circulated in January 1978. Greenaway was the first [[Amateur press association#Organization|Central Mailer]] and his successors included Maureen "Mo" James, Howard Stangroom, Les Chester and [[Steve Green (science fiction activist)|Steve Green]]. For most of its existence, up to thirty members of BAPA submitted multiple copies of at least two [[ISO 216|A4]] pages to the central mailer every two months. BAPA was disbanded on 17 August 2004<ref>Dave Langford, 'Infinitely Improbable', ''Ansible'' 206, (September 2004) ISSN 0265-9816</ref> with a final mailing distributed early in 2005. A one-off publication was also distributed under the name B-APA (sic) in 2005, in memory of Andy Roberts; a similar publication was announced in 2008, in memory of [[Steve Whitaker]].
Notable members of this association included [[Eddie Campbell]], [[Mark Finch]], [[Steve Green (science fiction activist)|Steve Green]], Martin Lock (later to launch [[Harrier Comics]]), Andy Roberts, Martin Skidmore (later editor of [[Trident Comics]]) and Steve Whitaker.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:British comics magazines]] [[Category:Comics-related organizations]] [[Category:Comics publications]] [[Category:1977 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1977]] [[Category:Communications and media organisations based in the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-comics-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}}
The '''Carnival in the [[Dominican Republic]]''' is a Dominican celebration that takes place throughout February; although some Dominicans (rarely) celebrate it during [[Holy Week]] in March. <ref>{{cite web|author=Janette Keys |url=http://www.colonialzone-dr.com/traditions-carnival.html |title=Carnaval Dominicano/ Dominican Republic Carnival Origin |website=Colonialzone-dr.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-12}}</ref> Dominicans are usually most festive on February 27th, which is the Dominican Independence Day. In [[Santo Domingo]], celebrations include a large military display with the Dominican air force, navy, and army. Festivities often include the wearing of colorful costumes that symbolize Dominican religious and traditional characters such as ''Calife'', ''Guloya'', and ''Diablo Cojuelo''. Festivities take place all over the island, with each town adding its own twist to the celebration.
==History== The "Christian" slave-owners who lived on the island would let their slaves have a celebration once a year so that they could get the "wild" out of their systems. The slave-owners considered this to be a "pagan" celebration, and therefore mixed "Christian" traditions into it and began to celebrate the event as well.
Evidence has been found in the ruins of La Vega Vieja (near the present day [[La Vega, Dominican Republic|La Vega]]) showing that Carnival has been celebrated in the Dominican Republic since 1510. The celebration originally consisted of the residents of the island dressing themselves as Moors and Christians.
Though it is not known for certain, it is thought that the colony of Santo Domingo was the first place in the Americas to have a [[Shrovetide|pre-Lenten]] costume. The celebration became a way to escape from the rigid religious traditions brought from the old world. By the late 1700s, the carnival had become a major celebration in the colony. Then on February 27, 1844, when the Dominican Republic won its independence from Haiti, the celebration grew even greater in popularity, as the country's Independence Day celebrations were combined into the pre-existing carnival celebrations.
==Symbols== The celebration is symbolized by an "upside-down Chicken", and its main character is the "Diablo Cojuelo" (Limping Devil).
==Characters== While there are many characters in the various versions of the carnival across the island, there are several prominent ones featured in most celebrations:
*'''Diablo Cojuelo''' (Limping Devil): is the main character of the carnival. A tale on the island says that this devil was banished to earth because of his childish pranks. When he hit the earth he hurt his leg, causing him to limp. While most of the communities across the island represent this character in different ways, several common practices are the use of a mask, a satanic suit, [[Jingle bell|sleigh bells]], and a whip or "Vejiga" (an animal bladder filled with air) to hit people in the streets (other "Diablos"). A Dominican tale claims that the mask is meant to represent the Spaniards who came to the island and enslaved and whipped the natives. *'''Roba la Gallina''' (Steal the Chicken): is a festivity that satires the fact that some people used to steal chickens from farms. This often consists of a man dressing up as a woman who just stole a chicken. This character often carries a large purse with candy inside for the crowd and is meant to be one of the more comical characters. [http://casadecampoliving.com/carnival-characters-1-roba-la-gallina/] *'''La Ciguapa''': is a female character who comes out at night. She is naked with very long black hair, and her feet are backwards. She enchants the men she comes across. *'''Los Indios''' (The Indians): are a group of men and women dressed in the typical native Taino Indian attire. They travel together representing Dominican origins.
==Celebration Passion's parade== There are many ways in which the carnival is celebrated, although most celebrations have several similarities: *They are held primarily on the main streets of the town or city. *People gather in the streets to watch parades. *Most of the disguised people carry a "Vejiga" or whip to hit people. *Typical music such as merengue and bachata is played throughout the celebration to add some excitement to it. *People wear colorful masks to represent religious figures.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Carnival around the world}}
[[Category:Entertainment events in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Cultural festivals in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Carnivals in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Religious festivals in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Winter events in the Dominican Republic]]

{{vgrelease|NA|December 11, 2000|EU|August 10, 2001}} | genre = [[Sports game|Sports]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Championship Surfer''''' is an [[extreme sport]]s [[sports video game|video game]] developed by [[Krome Studios]], published by [[Mattel Interactive]], and released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation]] and [[Dreamcast]] in 2000. {{clear}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | width = 26m | GR = (PS) 65.14%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps/437480-championship-surfer/index.html |title=Championship Surfer for PlayStation |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(DC) 58.42%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/dreamcast/914324-championship-surfer/index.html |title=Championship Surfer for Dreamcast |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(PC) 45.55%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/369692-championship-surfer/index.html |title=Championship Surfer for PC |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=December 11, 2014}} | MC = (DC) 61/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/dreamcast/championship-surfer |title=Championship Surfer for Dreamcast Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(PS) 57/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation/championship-surfer |title=Championship Surfer for PlayStation Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(PC) 47/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/championship-surfer |title=Championship Surfer for PC Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=December 11, 2014}} | EGM = 4/10{{cite journal |url=http://www.zdnet.com/egm/stories/main/0,11589,2668352,00.html |title=Championship Surfer (PS) |magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |date=February 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010211031156/http://www.zdnet.com/egm/stories/main/0%2C11589%2C2668352%2C00.html |archivedate=February 11, 2001 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014 |df= }} | GI = (PS) 7/10{{cite journal |last=Anderson |first=Paul |title=Championship Surfer (PS) |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=93 |date=January 2001 |page=105}}
(DC) 5/10{{cite journal |title=Championship Surfer (DC) |magazine=Game Informer |year=2001}} | GamePro = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web |author=Atomic Dawg |date=January 26, 2001 |url=http://www.gamepro.com/sega/dreamcast/games/reviews/10881.shtml |title=Championship Surfer Review for Dreamcast on GamePro.com |publisher=''[[GamePro]]'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050212135032/http://www.gamepro.com/sega/dreamcast/games/reviews/10881.shtml |archivedate=February 12, 2005 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} | GameRev = C{{cite web |last=Archer |first=Erik |date=January 2001 |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/xxxxxxxxx |title=Championship Surfer Review (DC) |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} | GSpot = (PS) 7.3/10{{cite web |last=Davis |first=Ryan |date=November 30, 2000 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/championship-surfer-review/1900-2659745/ |title=Championship Surfer Review (PS) |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(DC) 7.2/10{{cite web |last=Davis |first=Ryan |date=December 13, 2000 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/championship-surfer-review/1900-2664665/ |title=Championship Surfer Review (DC) |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(PC) 5.3/10{{cite web |last=Varanini |first=Giancarlo |date=November 29, 2000 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/championship-surfer-review/1900-2659258/ |title=Championship Surfer Review (PC) |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=December 11, 2014}} | GSpy = 8/10{{cite web |author=Mr. Domino |date=March 19, 2001 |url=http://www.planetdreamcast.com/games/reviews/championshipsurfer/ |title=Championship Surfer |publisher=[[GameSpy|PlanetDreamcast]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125092235/http://www.planetdreamcast.com/games/reviews/championshipsurfer/ |archivedate=January 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} | GameZone = 8.5/10{{cite web |last=Lafferty |first=Michael |date=November 13, 2000 |url=http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r15988.htm |title=Championship Surfer Review - PC |publisher=GameZone |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106021844/http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r15988.htm |archivedate=November 6, 2008 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} | IGN = (PS) 7.3/10{{cite web |last=Perry |first=Douglass C. |date=November 27, 2000 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/11/28/championship-surfer-2 |title=Championship Surfer (PS) |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(PC) 7.1/10{{cite web |last=Blevins |first=Tal |date=November 21, 2000 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/11/22/championship-surfer-3 |title=Championship Surfer (PC) |publisher=IGN |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}
(DC) 3.4/10{{cite web |last=Dunham |first=Jeremy |date=December 12, 2000 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/12/13/championship-surfer |title=Championship Surfer (DC) |publisher=IGN |accessdate=December 11, 2014}} | OPM = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite journal |last=Kennedy |first=Sam |url=http://www.zdnet.com/opm/stories/main/0,11891,2667599,00.html |title=Championship Surfer |magazine=[[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]] |date=February 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010418223109/http://www.zdnet.com/opm/stories/main/0%2C11891%2C2667599%2C00.html |archivedate=April 18, 2001 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014 |df= }} | PCGUS = 69%{{cite journal |last=Hachisu |first=Chiaki |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/reviews/archives/review_2001-02-13ad.html |title=Champion Surfer [sic] |magazine=[[PC Gamer]] |date=February 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040902023012/http://www.pcgamer.com/reviews/archives/review_2001-02-13ad.html |archivedate=September 2, 2004 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} }} The game was met with mixed to negative reception. [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave it a score of 65.14% and 57 out of 100 for the PlayStation version; 58.42% and 61 out of 100 for the Dreamcast version; and 45.55% and 47 out of 100 for the PC version. {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/championship-surfer}} [[Category:2000 video games]] [[Category:Dreamcast games]] [[Category:Mattel video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Surfing video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Krome Studios games]] {{sports-videogame-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Chimera Entertainment GmbH | type = [[Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung|GmbH]] | foundation = 2006 | founder = Christian Kluckner
Hendrik Lesser
Alexander Kehr | key_people = Christian Kluckner, Managing & Development Director
Hendrik Lesser, Managing Director
Andreas Katzig, Technical Director
Alexander Kehr, Creative Director
Christian Dreher, Art Director
Bernhard Falk, Head of Project Management | num_employees = 35+ | location = [[Munich]], [[Germany]] | industry = [[Video game industry]] | products = [[Video game]]s | homepage = [http://www.chimeraentertainment.de/en/ www.chimera-entertainment.de] }} '''Chimera Entertainment''' is a [[Germany|German]] [[Personal computer|PC]], mobile and [[video game development]] company and the biggest studio within the developer family of [[remote control productions]], which hosts Germany’s biggest developer network. As one of [[Germany]]´s leading development studio for entertainment software Chimera employs over 35 people in [[Munich]], Germany. The award winning studio developed more than 15 games on five platforms including [[Angry Birds Epic]],{{cite web |author=Viktor Pulz |title=Angry Birds Epic wurde von Chimera Entertainment entwickelt|url=http://www.newsslash.com/n/3330-angry-birds-epic-wurde-von-chimera-entertainment-entwickelt |work=Newsslash. |date=2014-06-13 |access-date=2014-06-20}}[http://www.chimeraentertainment.de/en/bloodstroke_en/ John Woo´s Bloodstroke]{{cite web |title=Bloodstroke|url=http://www.chimeraentertainment.de/en/bloodstroke_en/ |work=Chimera Entertainment, Homepage |access-date=2014-06-13}} and [http://www.chimeraentertainment.de/en/warstory-en/ Warstory – Europe in Flames].{{cite web |title=Warstory - Europe in Flames|url=http://www.chimeraentertainment.de/en/warstory-en/ |work=Chimera Entertainment, Homepage |access-date=2014-06-13}} Chimera Entertainment worked with partners like [[Rovio Entertainment|Rovio]], [[DeNA]], [[Audi]], [[Bigpoint]] and [[Koch Media]]. ==History== '''Chimera Entertainment''' was founded by the Mediadesign University of Applied Science (short MDH) graduates Alexander Kehr and Christian Kluckner together with Hendrik Lesser and his production house [http://www.r-control.de/index_en.php remote control productions] (short RCP) in [[Munich]], [[Germany]] in 2006. Kehr and Kluckner were among first game design graduates of the Munich-based design academy MDH. Kehr, having developed board and card games since he was six years old, and Kluckner already having four years of experience as a programmer, started working together while still attending the university and created the base for a team of young graduates eager to work within the games industry. The team of [http://www.r-control.de/index_en.php remote control productions] provided the framework while the company's [[Managing Director]] Lesser took over a part of the management of Chimera Entertainment. In May 2007 Chimera Entertainment received the LARA Start Up Award from the Bavarian Secretary of Commerce. The first project of Chimera Entertainment was ''Windchaser'' ([[Personal computer|PC]]), a [[Real-time computing|real time]] [[tactical role-playing game]] set in Ensai, an original fantasy world created by Kehr himself. June 2009 saw the release of ''Train your Brain with Dr. Kawashima'', created in cooperation with BBG Entertainment. This [[brain training]] application for [[Personal computer|PC]] and [[Macintosh|Mac]] is based on the studies of Japanese [[Neuroscientist]] [[Ryuta Kawashima]]. In cooperation with [[Bigpoint Games]] Chimera Entertainment released ''Warstory - Europe in Flames'', a [[Microsoft Silverlight]] Browsergame featuring [[Real-time computing|real time]] battles set in [[World War II]]. In the following years Chimera released several other games on various platforms with ''[[Angry Birds Epic]]'' ([[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]]) being the latest game made by Chimera Entertainment in cooperation with [[Rovio Entertainment|Rovio]]. ==Releases (chronological)== Chimera's debut title called ''Windchaser'' ([[Personal computer|PC]]) was published in May 2008, followed by several commissioned projects including ''Train Your Brain With Dr. Kawashima'' ([[Personal computer|PC]], [[Mac OS|Mac]]), ''memory HD'', ''Demolition Dash'' and ''Happy Hills'' (all [[iOS]]). In 2010, Chimera Entertainment launched its first MMO browsergame [[Warstory – Europe in Flames]] in cooperation with Bigpoint. In 2012 Chimera Entertainment released in collaboration with different publishing partners the MMO browser games ''Skylancer: Battle for Horizon'' and ''Mission: Genesis'' and ''Word Wonders'', ''Sara’s Cooking Class'' and ''Towers & Dungeons'' on mobile platforms. The latest game developed by Chimera in cooperation with [[Rovio Entertainment|Rovio]] is [[Angry Birds Epic]] ([[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]]). {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! The '''classical unities''', '''Aristotelian unities''', or '''three unities''' are rules for [[drama]] derived from a passage in [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]''. In their [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] form they are as follows: #''unity of action'': a play should have one action that it follows, with minimal subplots. #''unity of time'': the action in a play should occur over a period of no more than 24 hours. #''unity of place'': a play should exist in a single physical space and should not attempt to compress geography, nor should the stage represent more than one place. ==Aristotle's unities== Aristotle dealt with the unity of action in some detail, under the general subject of "definition of tragedy", where he wrote: "serious, complete in itself and of a certain magnitude".
Now, according to our definition, Tragedy is an imitation of an action that is complete, and whole, and of a certain magnitude[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/ari/poe/poe08.htm Aristotle's ''Poetics'', VII]. … As therefore, in the other imitative arts, the imitation is one when the object imitated is one, so the plot, being an imitation of an action, must imitate one action and that a whole, the structural union of the parts being such that, if any one of them is displaced or removed, the whole will be disjointed and disturbed. For a thing whose presence or absence makes no visible difference, is not an organic part of the whole.[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/ari/poe/poe09.htm Aristotle's ''Poetics'', VIII].
His only reference to the time in the fictive world is in a distinction between the [[Epic poetry|epic]] and [[tragedy|tragic]] forms:
Epic poetry agrees with Tragedy in so far as it is an imitation in [[Verse (poetry)|verse]] of characters of a higher type. They differ, in that Epic poetry admits but one kind of metre, and is narrative in form. They differ, again, in their length: for Tragedy endeavours, as far as possible, to confine itself to a single revolution of the sun, or but slightly to exceed this limit; whereas the Epic action has no limits of time.Aristotle's ''Poetics'', V.
Unlike his prescriptive attitude regarding the plot (unity of action), Aristotle here merely remarks on the typical duration of a tragedy's action, and does not suggest any kind of imperative that it always ought to be so. He was writing after the golden age of [[Greek drama]], and many [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] playwrights wrote plays that do not fit within these conventions. Aristotle does not actually mention the neoclassical unity of place at all. However, the prevalent interpretation of his ''Poetics'' during the Middle Ages inclined toward interpreting his comment on time as another "unity". ==European literature== {{refimprove section|date=October 2014}} [[Italy|Italian]] critics of the 16th century, from [[Lodovico Castelvetro]] onwards, and then [[French literature of the 17th century|17th-century French]] critics, proponents of the [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] movement, both expanded Aristotle's descriptions. The result was to make them into prescriptions for structuring plays. French drama of the 17th century, particularly that of [[Molière]] and [[Jean Racine|Racine]], was highly regular, and [[Pierre Corneille|Corneille]] incurred harsh criticism for departing from the unities in ''[[Le Cid]]''. The [[England|English]] dramatists writing for the [[English Renaissance theatre|Elizabethan and Jacobean stage]] were largely unaware of these structures. By the later 17th century, however, English dramatists (under the influence of French criticism picked up by those in exile during the [[English Interregnum]]) did begin to assess their own plays according to these rules. Thus, [[John Dryden]], among many others, compares the "irregular" [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] (only two of Shakespeare's plays conform to the unities – ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' and ''[[The Tempest]]'') with the "regular" [[Dryden]] in his ''[[Essay of Dramatick Poesie]]'' (1668), and makes use of the unity of time in this passage criticizing [[Shakespearean histories|Shakespeare's history plays]].
... if you consider the Historical Playes of Shakespeare, they are rather so many Chronicles of Kings, or the business many times of thirty or forty years, crampt into a representation of two hours and a half, which is not to imitate or paint Nature, but rather to draw her in miniature, to take her in little; to look upon her through the wrong end of a Perspective, and receive her Images not onely much less, but infinitely more imperfect then the life: this instead of making a Play delightful, renders it ridiculous.Dryden, ''An Essay of Dramatick Poesie'' (1668), para. 56.
However, Dryden declared Shakespeare "incomparable" because of his disregard for convention:
... in most of the irregular Playes of Shakespeare or [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher]] (for Ben Johnson's are for the most part regular) there is a more masculine fancy and greater spirit in all the writing, then[sic] there is in any of the French.Dryden, ''An Essay of Dramatick Poesie'' (1668), para. 84.
[[Alexander Pope]] criticizes the violation of the unities in his ''[[Dunciad]]''. In the 1728 version of the poem, the goddess Dulness notes that "Time himself stands still at her command,/ Realms shift their place, and Ocean turns to land" (''Dunciad'' 1728, i, 69–70). Additionally, he notes a violation of unity of action, as tragedy and comedy were mixed. [[Samuel Johnson]], too, applied the unities to drama in his ''Prefaces to Shakespeare''. He was well aware that Aristotle had only recommended the unity of action, and knew that rules must serve drama, not vice versa:
Whether Shakespeare knew the unities, and rejected them by design, or deviated from them by happy ignorance, it is, I think, impossible to decide, and useless to inquire. We may reasonably suppose, that, when he rose to notice, he did not want the counsels and admonitions of scholars and critics, and that he at last deliberately persisted in a practice, which he might have begun by chance. As nothing is essential to the fable, but unity of action, and as the unities of time and place arise evidently from false assumptions, and, by circumscribing the extent of the drama, lessen its variety, I cannot think it much to be lamented, that they were not known by him, or not observed: Nor, if such another poet could arise, should I very vehemently reproach him, that his first act passed at Venice, and his next in Cyprus. Such violations of rules merely positive, become the comprehensive genius of Shakespeare…Johnson, ''Preface to his Edition of Shakespeare's Plays (1765),'' ff. a7r–a7v, para. 59.
[[John Pitcher]], in his [[Arden Shakespeare]] Third Series edition of ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'' (2010), argues that Shakespeare was familiar with the unities due to an English translation of ''Poetics'' that became popular around 1608, and that The Winter's Tale is intentionally breaking all the rules. The classical unities were influential in dramatic criticism until [[Victor Hugo]]'s ''[[Hernani (drama)|Hernani]]'' (1830); one of the things that made that play controversial at its debut was its violation of these rules of [[classicism]]. In the Spanish theatrical tradition, there is [[Lope de Vega]]'s ''Arte nuevo de hacer comedias'' of 1609, which is a defense of the new form for writing and representation of [[Spanish Golden Age|Golden Age]] Spanish theatre. Lope's ''Arte nuevo'' is a 389 verse poem which explicitly defends his and other dramaturges, distancing from Aristotelian unities of theatre. ==See also== *[[History of theater]] *[[Theatre technique]] *[[Theatrical constraints]] ==Notes== ==References== * {{cite book |author=Aristotle |authorlink=Aristotle |year=1907 |title=The Poetics of Aristotle |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/1974 |format=Project Gutenberg e-text # 1974 |edition=4th |others=Samuel Henry Butcher (trans.) |publisher=Macmillan |location=London|oclc=3113766}} * {{cite book |author=Dryden, John |authorlink=John Dryden |year=1668 |title=An Essay of Dramatick Poesie |url=http://andromeda.rutgers.edu/~jlynch/Texts/drampoet.html |editor=Jack Lynch (Ed.)|format=Online reprint |location=London |publisher=Henry Harringman |oclc=4969880}} * {{cite book |author=Johnson, Samuel |authorlink=Samuel Johnson |origyear=1765 |year=2005 |title=Mr. Johnson's Preface To his Edition of Shakespear's Plays |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/html/1807/4350/displayprose274e.html |format=Online reprint |edition=online edition published by RPO Editors, Department of English, and University of Toronto Press as ''Samuel Johnson (1709-1784): Preface to his Edition of Shakespeare's Plays (1765)''. |others=Ian Lancashire (Ed.)|publisher=J. and R. Tonson and others |location=London |oclc=10834559}} ==External links== * {{gutenberg|no=1974|name=The Poetics of Aristotle'', translated by Samuel Henry Butcher}} * {{gutenberg|no=5429|name=Preface to Shakespeare'', by Samuel Johnson}} [[Category:Drama]] [[Category:Theatre]] [[Category:History of theatre]] [[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Style (fiction)]]

{{BLP sources|date=March 2018|reason=no sourcing or content about her 2014 and 2016 elections, or about whether she's running in 2018}}
{{Infobox State Senator | image = |name=Colleen Madigan Lachowicz |state_house=Maine |district=110th |term_start= December 7, 2016 |term_end= |preceded= [[Henry Beck]] |succeeded= |state_senate1=Maine |state1=Maine |district1=25th |term_start1= December 5, 2012 |term_end1= December 3, 2014 |preceded1= [[Thomas Martin (Maine politician)|Tom Martin]] |succeeded1= [[Scott Cyrway]] |birth_date= {{b-da|January 22, 1964}} |birth_place= |death_date= |death_place= |spouse= |profession=Social Worker |religion= |party=Democrat |website= }} '''Colleen Madigan''' (born January 22, 1964) is an American politician and [[social worker]] from [[Maine]]. Under the name Colleen Lachowicz, the [[Maine Democratic Party|Democrat]] from [[Waterville, Maine|Waterville]] was elected to the [[Maine Senate]] from the 25th District. Her race attracted international attention when the [[Republican Party of Maine]] issued press releases condemning her for playing the online video game ''[[World of Warcraft]]'', claiming her "disturbing alter-ego" and "time-consuming double life" made her unfit to hold public office.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2213180/Colleen-Lachowicz-Maine-state-senate-candidate-outed-World-Warcraft-player.html#ixzz28TMQICcJ Zennie, Michael. "Democrat state senate candidate's 'disturbing double life' as 'Santiaga' a level 85 orc assassin in World of Warcraft" ''[[Daily Mail]]'' 4 October 2012]</ref><ref>[http://www.onlinesentinel.com/politics/Lachowicz.html Shepherd, Michael. "Maine Republicans attack candidate for playing World of Warcraft" ''Morning Sentinel'' October 4, 2012]</ref> She was defeated for re-election two years later by Republican [[Scott Cyrway]].
She returned to her maiden name, Colleen Madigan, in 2014 and was elected to the [[Maine House of Representatives]]'s District 110 in 2016, winning with 2305 votes to 1661 for Republican Mark Andre.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/maine-state-house-district-110 "Maine State House District 110" ''New York Times'' website]</ref><ref name="colleenmadigan.com">[http://www.colleenmadigan.com Colleen Madigan] "2016 campaign web site".</ref> (Democratic incumbent [[Henry Beck]] was not a candidate for re-election, and Madigan was unopposed in the primary.)
== Background == Coleen Madigan was born January 22, 1964.<ref>[http://www.onlinesentinel.com/community/2012-central-maine-candidates.html "Central Maine House and Senate Candidates 2012"] ''[[Morning Sentinel]]''. [https://www.webcitation.org/6C0MrZy3h?url=http://www.onlinesentinel.com/community/2012-central-maine-candidates.html Archived] from the original on November 7, 2012. Retrieved November 7, 2012.</ref> According to her campaign biography, Lachowicz had been working since she was 15 years old. After graduating from [[William Paterson College]] with a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[sociology]] in 1987, she worked with adults with mental illness, then spent a year in Eastern Europe providing supportive counseling services to international students. She returned to the U.S., and earned a [[Master of Social Work]] from [[Boston College]] in 1999. She has spent 25 years as a social worker and lives in Waterville.<ref name="onlinesentinel.com">[http://www.onlinesentinel.com/news/district-25-democrats-similar-different_2012-06-01.html Calder, Amy.] "District 25 Democrats similar, different; Senate hopefuls from Waterville to face off June 12 in primary" ''[[Morning Sentinel]]'' June 2, 2012.</ref>
== 2012 Election == Lachowicz, a long-time Democratic activist and advocate on women's issues, won a June 12, 2012 primary election against Dana Hernandez, with 827 votes (52.3%) to Hernandez' 755 (47.7%).<ref>[http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/files/elections/2012/by_state/ME_Page_0612.html?SITE=CSPANELN&SECTION=POLITICS ''C-SPAN'', "AP Election Results - Maine Summary Vote Totals"]</ref> She faced Martin, who ran unopposed in his own primary, on November 6, 2012.<ref>[http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/2012/2012candidate.pdf ''Maine Secretary of State'' "Primary Candidate List," June 12, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018012341/http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/2012/2012candidate.pdf |date=October 18, 2012 }}</ref> The 25th district covers [[Albion, Maine|Albion]], [[Benton, Maine|Benton]], [[Clinton, Maine|Clinton]], [[Unity, Kennebec County, Maine|Unity Township]], Waterville and [[Winslow, Maine|Winslow]] in [[Kennebec County, Maine|Kennebec County]], and [[Detroit, Maine|Detroit]] and [[Pittsfield, Maine|Pittsfield]] in [[Somerset County, Maine|Somerset County]].<ref name="onlinesentinel.com"/>
=== Attack on Lachowicz and gaming === The website "Colleen's World" was set up by the Republican Party of Maine to [[outing|"out"]] her as a player of the [[Massively multiplayer online role-playing game]] (MMORPG) ''[[World of Warcraft]]'' (her "main" character is a level 100 [[orc#Warcraft|orc]] [[rogue (character class)#Other games|rogue]] named Santiaga).<ref>[http://www.colleensworld.com Colleen's World | The Online World of Maine State Senate Candidate Colleen LachowiczColleen's World]</ref> The site displayed several messages posted by Lachowicz to sites such as ''[[The Daily Kos]]'', stating her desire to "go and hunt down [[Grover Norquist]] and drown HIM in [her] bathtub" (referencing a comment Norquist made on shrinking the government "to the size where we can drown it in the bathtub")<ref name="1115.ORG">{{cite web | title=Maybe They Forgot What "Conservative" Means | url=http://www.1115.org/2004/09/28/maybe-they-forgot-what-conservative-means/ | year=2004 | accessdate=September 28, 2004 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071022165714/http://www.1115.org/2004/09/28/maybe-they-forgot-what-conservative-means/ | archivedate=October 22, 2007 | df= }}</ref> and comments about stabbing and poisons (in ''World of Warcraft'', rogues rely heavily on daggers and poisons).<ref>{{wowpedia|Rogue}}</ref> The website said "In Colleen’s online fantasy world, she gets away with crude, vicious and violent comments" and "Maine needs a State Senator that lives in the real world, not in Colleen’s fantasy world." They also sent out a press release titled "Disturbing Alter-Ego Revealed" which accused her of living a "time-consuming double life."<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-19842704 'World of Warcraft hobby sparks US political row' BBC News: Technology 5 October, 2012]</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/ingame/republicans-out-democrat-world-warcraft-witch-hunt-6283586 Benedetti, Winda. "Republicans out Democrat in 'World of Warcraft' witch hunt" NBCNews.com TECH InGame October 4, 2012]</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/ingame/world-warcraft-playing-candidate-im-real-person-1C6303203 Benedetti, Winda. "'World of Warcraft'-playing candidate: 'I'm a real person'" NBCNews.com TECH InGame October 5, 2012]</ref>
In response, Lachowicz said, "I think it’s weird that I’m being targeted for playing online games. Apparently I’m in good company since there are 183 million other Americans who also enjoy online games. What’s next? Will I be ostracized for playing ''[[Angry Birds]]'' or ''[[Words with Friends]]''?" She added, "What’s really weird is that the Republicans are going after my hobbies instead of talking about their record while they’ve been running Augusta for the last two years. Instead of talking about what they’re doing for Maine people, they’re making fun of me for playing video games. Did you know that more people over the age of 50 play video games than under the age of 18? As a gamer, I’m in good company with folks like [[Jodie Foster]], [[Vin Diesel]], [[Mike Myers]], and [[Robin Williams]]. Maybe it’s the Republican Party that is out of touch."<ref>[http://www.colleenlachowicz.com/?p=106 Lachowicz, Colleen. "Statement on Attacks" Official website; October 4, 2012]</ref>
Martin said he was unaware of the party's attacks on Lachowicz until contacted by reporters, and he didn’t condone them. Both candidates were declared "clean election candidates," meaning they were both pledged to abstain from negative campaigning, and could only spend the amount they receive from [[Clean Elections|public financing]] and a limited amount of donations. A number of gamers raised money for organizations which support Lachowicz' candidacy, since her campaign could not solicit or receive any donations;<ref>[https://secure.actblue.com/page/santiaga "Friends of Santiaga: Support A Gamer Who's Under Attack" page at actblue.com]</ref> but she said she would rather not become the poster girl for a game she had almost completely stopped playing due to time pressure.<ref>[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1012/82074.html Friess, Steve. "'Warcraft' candidate: Gaming is misunderstood" Politico.com October 5, 2012]</ref> The Maine Republican Party filed an ethics complaint, alleging that she cheated by posting on the ActBlue website, and claiming that this constituted improperly coordinating with political action committees to solicit campaign contributions. The [[bipartisan]] Maine Ethics Commission rejected this accusation by a 5-0 vote in Lachowicz’s favor.<ref>[http://bangordailynews.com/2012/11/01/politics/ethics-commission-clears-world-of-warcraft-candidate-of-wrongdoing/ Stone, Matthew. "Ethics commission clears ''World of Warcraft'' candidate of wrongdoing" ''[[Bangor Daily News]]'' November 1, 2012]</ref>
The attacks attracted international attention, including articles from [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']], the [[BBC]], [[Forbes (magazine)|''Forbes'']], [[Slate.com]], [[Politico.com]] and a piece on the satirical news program ''[[The Colbert Report]]''.<ref>http://techland.time.com/2012/10/10/maine-republican-party-playing-world-of-warcraft-makes-you-unfit-for-office/#ixzz28uP5JRjX Peckham, Matt. "Maine Republican Party: Playing World of Warcraft Makes You Unfit for Office" ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' October 10, 2012</ref> <ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/maine-state-senate-candidate-fire-world-warcraft-persona-article-1.1177040#ixzz2917us6VN Roberts, Christine. "Maine state Senate candidate Colleen Lachowicz under fire for 'World of Warcraft' persona" ''[[New York Daily News]]'' October 7, 2012]</ref><ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaelpeck/2012/10/05/is-being-a-gamer-a-political-death-sentence/ Peck, Michael. "Being a Gamer a Political Death Sentence?" ''Forbes'' Technology. October 7, 2012]</ref><ref>[http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2012/10/05/colleen_lachowicz_s_world_of_warcraft_habit_gop_attacks_her_level_85_prowess_.html Kilkenny, Katie. "GOP Goes After World of Warcraft-Loving Candidate" Browbeat: ''Slate'''s Culture Blog October 5, 2012]</ref> After the controversy broke, she told the press that she had had to put her ''WoW'' playing on hold due to time pressure; but [[Blizzard Entertainment]], she said, had sent her a copy of ''[[Mists of Pandaria]]'', the latest ''WoW'' [[expansion pack]], signed by the entire development team, and she hoped to play it after catching up on lost sleep.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/ingame/world-warcraft-playing-candidate-wins-election-1C6892843 Benedetti, Winda. "''World of Warcraft''-playing candidate wins election" ''NBCNews.com: Technology: InGame'' November 7, 2012]</ref>
=== Endorsements === On October 11, 2012, the [[Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee]] declared Lachowicz one of their "2012 Essential Races: Grassroots Nominees", stating that she had received the second-largest number of nominations from grassroots activists. Referencing the ''World of Warcraft'' attack, the DLCC claimed that the controversy had made hers "perhaps the most nationally-watched legislative race in the country right now".<ref>[http://dlcc.org/2012Races_Grassroots_choices "2012 Essential Races: Grassroots Nominees", Democratic Legislative Leadership Committee website; October 11, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015011734/http://dlcc.org/2012Races_Grassroots_choices |date=October 15, 2012 }}</ref>
=== Outcome === Lachowicz was the winner in the general election, unseating Martin with 8,666 votes to his 7,753. Her overwhelming majority in Waterville (4,224 to 2,318) overcame her opponent's narrow leads in all the other municipalities: he won Winslow by 2,007-1,921, Pittsfield 990-702, Detroit 179-163, Clinton 837-705, Benton 824-579; and Albion 598-372.<ref>[http://www.onlinesentinel.com/news/Lachowicz-has-early-lead-in-state-Senate-25-race.html Calder, Amy. "Lachowicz unseats Martin in Senate District 25: Race drew national attention over Republican attacks on winner's online gaming, Internet posts" ''[[Morning Sentinel]]'' November 7, 2012]</ref>
