{{Infobox television | show_name = Con Man | image = ConManTitlecard.png | image_alt = The titlecard logo for Con Man. | genre = [[Comedy]] | creator = [[Alan Tudyk]] | starring = {{Plain list| * Alan Tudyk * [[Nathan Fillion]] * [[Mindy Sterling]] }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 25 | list_episodes = #Episodes | executive_producer = {{Plain list| * [[PJ Haarsma]] * Alan Tudyk * Nathan Fillion}} | editor = {{Plain list| * Abe Levy * Ryan Brown * Jeremy Jurin}} | cinematography = Jay Hunter | composer = {{Plain list| * Stephen Phillips * Tim Paruszkiewicz}} | runtime = 10–17 minutes | channel = [[Vimeo]] {{small|(season 1)}}
Comic-Con HQ {{small|(season 2)}} | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | last_aired = {{End date|2017|1|26}} | website = http://conmantheseries.com/ }} '''''Con Man''''' is an American comedy web series created, written, directed by, and starring [[Alan Tudyk]]. The series follows cult science fiction actor Wray Nerely (Tudyk), as he tours the [[fan convention|convention]] circuit. Tudyk, one of the stars of the 2002 science fiction TV show ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'', based ''Con Man'' loosely upon his own experiences. The series is co-produced by [[PJ Haarsma]] and by [[Nathan Fillion]], who also co-stars in it. Crowdfunded through [[Indiegogo]], ''Con Man'' set records for crowdfunding a web series by raising more than $1 million in 24 hours and more than $3.1 million overall. The series premiered on September 30, 2015, on [[Vimeo]], with the first season consisting of 13 episodes. The second season premiered on December 8, 2016 on Comic-Con HQ, Comic-Con's subscription streaming video service and consisted of 12 episodes. In 2017, the series was acquired by [[Syfy]] and had its television debut on September 9, 2017, where the episodes were combined to produce half-hour installments for airing. == Plot == Wray Nerely (Tudyk) is a struggling actor who starred as a spaceship pilot on ''Spectrum'', a canceled science fiction series that went on to become a cult classic. Wray's good friend Jack Moore (Nathan Fillion), who starred as the ship's captain, has become an [[A-list]] movie star. Frustrated by Jack's success and his lack thereof, Wray travels the science fiction convention circuit, makes appearances at comic book stores, and visits pop culture events. He navigates the odd people and incidents he encounters along the way while learning to love the fans he has.{{cite web|title=‘Firefly’ Stars Alan Tudyk, Nathan Fillion Reunite for Crowdfunded ‘Con Man’ Series|url=https://variety.com/2015/digital/news/con-man-alan-tudyk-nathan-fillion-series-firefly-1201450339/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}{{cite web|title=‘Firefly’ Friends Alan Tudyk and Nathan Fillion Reunite For Web Series ‘Con Man’|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/con-man-alan-tudyk-nathan-fillion/|work=[[SlashFilm]]|first=Germain|last=Lussier|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} == Cast == === Main cast === * [[Alan Tudyk]] as Wray Nerely, a struggling actor who formerly starred on ''Spectrum'' as pilot Cash Wayne. To his dissatisfaction, he is pigeonholed into science fiction roles, the only non–science fiction role being an episode of ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]''.{{refn|group=note|Tudyk's guest appearance in an episode of ''Justified'' was credited as Wray Nerely.{{cite web|last1=Bierly|first1=Mandi|title='Justified' postmortem: EP Graham Yost dissects 'Shot All to Hell'|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/02/05/justified-shot-all-to-hell/2 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=February 5, 2015}}}} Tudyk said of his character, "Wray struggles with his career and he's very unhappy in his career. Even though he's a huge star at conventions, he comes home to his one-bedroom apartment and hopes to get a guest star spot on ''NCIS: Topeka''."{{cite web|title='Firefly' stars reunite for crowdfunded Web series|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/firefly-stars-reunite-for-crowdfunded-webseries-about-cons/|work=[[CNET]]|first=Amanda|last=Kooser|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} Wray's former role as a pilot on a canceled science fiction show and later cult hit is a nod to Tudyk's role on ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]''. * [[Nathan Fillion]] as Jack Moore, Wray's good friend who formerly starred on ''Spectrum'' as Captain James Raaker. Unlike Wray, Jack has "gone on to incredible action-hero stardom, like [[Matt Damon]]" and so "is a daily reminder of what Wray wishes he had".{{cite web|title=Nathan Fillion and Alan Tudyk Return To Fandom In New Series ''Con Man'' |url=http://io9.com/nathan-fillion-and-alan-tudyk-return-to-fandom-in-new-s-1690725690 |publisher=[[io9]] |first=Jason |last=Shankel |date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} Tudyk said of Fillion's involvement, "Nathan was an obvious choice for this project from the beginning. I’ve wanted to work with him again since ''Firefly'', really." Jack's former role as a captain on a canceled science fiction show and later cult hit is a nod to Fillion's role on ''Firefly''. * [[Mindy Sterling]] as Bobbie, Wray's [[Talent agent|booking agent]]. She receives fifteen percent of everything Wray receives, and to increase this amount, she downgrades Wray's flights and accommodations so the convention will pay him the difference in cash. Though it is observed she is not conventionally attractive, she often has sex with convention guests. She was formerly an actress and, though is not famous, has a varied filmography ranging from a science fiction [[B movie]] to [[snuff film]]s. Tudyk stated Bobbie is his favorite character and said she "represents the 'carnie' aspect of the conventions". === Recurring cast === Of the "kooky" people who populate the series, Tudyk emphasized, "the kooky people in ''Con Man'' are not the fans. [The fans] are the heroes of this. The kooky people are the people who work in the conventions. [...] It's the people that we've met along the way that are pulling the strings behind the curtain, in addition to kooky celebrities." * [[Casper Van Dien]] as John Boutell, the [[bartender]] at every bar, regardless of its location. * [[Sean Astin]] as himself, an actor who played [[Samwise Gamgee]] in ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' film series. While he advises Wray to accept his status as a beloved cult icon and gladly interacts with his fans, he also encourages Wray to use the fans' devotion for material gain, such as to upgrade his flight from coach to first class. * [[Ari Stidham]] as 1st class fan, a ''Spectrum'' fan. He reneges on an agreement to give his first-class plane seat to Wray if Wray signs multiple items, causing Wray to later refuse to return the fan's "lucky pen". The fan reveals this during a panel, foiling Wray's attempt to calm the enraged audience. He is among those who chase Wray. * [[Felicia Day]] as Karen, Wray's enthusiastic assistant for the duration of the convention he attends in episodes two through four. She always dresses exactly as he does in case she needs to be his decoy, and because of this, he is able to escape an enraged group of fans. * [[Nolan North]] as Jerry Lansing, a [[motion capture]] artist, second best after [[Andy Serkis]], and self-proclaimed "mocap king". He reappears in "Voiced Over" recording voice-over work for a video game. The character was originally named Nigel Thrice; Jerry Lansing was a character originally created by North while he worked on the ''[[Uncharted]]'' series. * [[Tricia Helfer]] as Louise, a woman attending a doll convention who treats her baby dolls as if they are real infants. Though Wray finds this behavior creepy, he becomes enamored with her and strives to gain her affection. Their short-lived relationship ends when Wray breaks her porcelain doll Isabelle in "Doll Faced". * [[Leslie Jordan]] as himself, an actor. Though he is widely believed to be gay, he admits to Wray that he is pretending so that he can attract older [[Conservatism|politically conservative]] women through the "corrosive black lie" that sexuality is a choice. He becomes enamored with Bobbie, especially after she convinces him she is conservative. * [[Sean Maher]] as himself, a gay actor who starred in the ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'' television series and the related film ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]''. He mistakenly believes Bobbie is male, then interprets Wray's correction as she is [[transgender]], and becomes enamored with her and how "courageous" he perceives her to be. * [[Alison Haislip]] as Faith, Jack Moore's new assistant who oversees his day to day schedule. As a fan of the original series ''Spectrum'', she starts a flirty relationship with Wray although someone or something always seems to come between them. * [[Liza Lapira]] as Brenda, an actress who played Dr. Chu on ''Spectrum''. * [[Henry Rollins]] as Stutter, an actor who played Hashen on ''Spectrum''. * [[Skyler Day]] as Tiffany, an actress who played Ketheria on ''Spectrum''. * Skylar Haarsma as Young Tiffany, during the time ''Spectrum'' was on the air. * [[Amy Acker]] as Dawn, an actress who played Bree on ''Spectrum''. == Episodes == {{Series overview | released = y | color1 = #A5C6E0 | link1 = #Season 1 (2015) | episodes1 = 13 | start1 = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | end1 = {{End date|2015|10|21}} | color2 = #EFDF2B | link2 = #Season 2 (2016–17) | episodes2 = 12 | start2 = {{Start date|2016|12|8}} | end2 = {{End date|2017|1|26}} }} === Season 1 (2015) === {{Episode table |background=#A5C6E0 |overall=5 |season=5 |title=23 |director=14 |writer=33 |airdate=20 |released=y |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = Stalled | DirectedBy = [[Alan Tudyk]] | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | ShortSummary = Wray Nerely flies to a weekend-long convention, and to his dismay, he is in [[Coach class|coach]]. In the bathroom, he reluctantly signs a magazine cover featuring his ''Spectrum'' costar Jack Moore. He receives a call about a [[Clint Eastwood]] [[Western (genre)|Western]] film, but because he cannot audition in person, he must send a taped audition instead. When Wray expresses discontent over fan interactions, [[Sean Astin]] (himself) encourages him to accept his status as beloved cult figure and use it to upgrade his seat. Astin's use of the word "retard" in the sense of "to impede or hinder" encourages Wray to say it. A ''Spectrum'' fan in first-class (Ari Stidham) reneges on the agreement to switch seats with Wray when Astin convinces another fan out of the adjacent seat. Wray is forced to his seat by the [[flight attendant]] (Samantha Smith) and [[Federal Air Marshal Service|Federal Air Marshal]] Cahoots ([[Wil Wheaton]]). | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = Cash Poor | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | ShortSummary = The flight in coach gives Wray back pain. Bobbie ([[Mindy Sterling]]), Wray's [[booking agent]], knows that he is auditioning for an Eastwood Western and offers to help him. He refuses her help and insists that no one is supposed to know about the project. He meets Karen ([[Felicia Day]]), a volunteer assigned to be his personal assistant for the duration of the convention. They quickly work through Wray's autograph line that he can rehearse the Eastwood script. Bobbie's loud insistence forces Wray to accept her help. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = Behind the Lines | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | ShortSummary = Bobbie's flawed character interpretation and overacting makes rehearsing difficult, and Wray tells her to leave. Jerry Lansing ([[Nolan North]]) gives Wray a painkiller for his back, though warns that it is potent with alcohol. Jack Moore ([[Nathan Fillion]]) calls Wray and expresses his regret over his canceled convention appearance and agrees to "put in a good word" with Eastwood. Wray, Jerry, and Astin meet fans at a VIP party. Despite the warning, Wray begins drinking and, taking Astin's revised advice to be himself, answers fan questions without tact. The meet and greet turns into a night of hard drinking and partying. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = Retarding It All Up | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|9|30}} | ShortSummary = The next morning, Wray learns he recorded and sent his audition tape during his alcohol and painkiller induced [[Blackout (drug-related amnesia)|blackout]]. During his panel, he struggles to deflect questions about comments he made during the VIP party, including about the Eastwood film. His use of the word "retard" insults the audience, and his attempt to apologize worsens the situation. He distracts most of the crowd when Jack returns a phone call, but the disabled fans pursue him. Karen acts as a decoy, and he escapes. Astin reports that an online video of Wray talking about the film cost him the role. Wray gives Astin fan-made [[bourbon ball]]s, which induce diarrhea, as payback for encouraging Wray to use the word "retard". | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = Baby Boom | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|7}} | ShortSummary = Wray meets Louise ([[Tricia Helfer]]), who is attending the doll convention held alongside the science fiction convention. Though he is smitten with her, he finds it creepy that she treats her porcelain baby doll Isabelle as if it were real. However, Louise says she "adopted" the doll to help recover from the death of her son. Bobbie enters a [[cosplay]] contest judged by Wray, [[Leslie Jordan]] (himself), and [[Sean Maher]] (himself). Though she is initially upset that her sexy costume will not sway Leslie and Maher, who are both gay, Leslie is pretending and Maher believes she is male, interpreting Wray's attempt to correct him as Bobbie is transgender. The pair become enamoured with her. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = A Fluid Thing | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|7}} | ShortSummary = Bobbie agrees to meet Leslie and Maher at the hotel bar: Leslie at six and Maher at seven. Wray meets Ron Slackskin ([[Dileep Rao]]), who made an action figure of Wray as Cash Wayne that "slams" its fist down. Wray loves it with a fatherly affection and names it Wray Wray. At the ''Spectrum'' booth on the convention floor, Ron reports that all of the other Cash action figures sold out in an online pre-sale. A fan offers to buy Wray Wray at a premium, prompting Bobbie to start an auction. Louise witnesses this and disapproves. Wray refuses to sell Wray Wray and chases after Louise. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | EpisodeNumber2 = 7 | Title = Doll Faced | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|7}} | ShortSummary = Wray apologizes to Louise, and his compliments and his affection for Wray Wray lead her to reevaluate her opinion of him. She agrees to have dinner with Wray and Wray Wray. Bobbie's attempts to court Leslie and Maher separately backfires. The men scuffle at the bar, knocking Bobbie over, and she storms out. Wray's dinner with Louise starts well, and she trusts him to look after Isabelle while she goes to the bathroom. He is distracted by a call from Jack, and the doll slips out of its high chair and breaks. In her grief, Louise reveals that her son was a plastic doll. Wray tells her that she has never had real children, and she tells him that Wray Wray's motion feature looks like it is masturbating. Wray goes to Bobbie to have the action figure recalled, but she is busy having sex with Leslie and Maher. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | EpisodeNumber2 = 8 | Title = Voiced Over | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|14}} | ShortSummary = Wray, Jerry, and [[Milo Ventimiglia]] (himself) record voicework for an action video game. Because his voice "doesn't naturally convey strength", the voice director Grace ([[Gina Torres]]) has Wray voice Marion, a frightened and dying soldier. To prove he can sound "manly", he affects the voice of Rigamarole, a caricature of a black man he voiced in the racist cartoon ''Wassup, Bitch?'', and he is kicked off the project. Jack, drunk, calls Wray and offers a film role because he misses working with Wray. He tells him to come over so they can talk about it. Milo asks Wray to appear at a comic book store opening that night in his place. Wray explains he cannot because he and Jack are making a movie, prompting Milo to ask if it is a ''Spectrum'' film. Wray explains it is not. Wray finally agrees to go upon learning it pays $5000. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | EpisodeNumber2 = 9 | Title = Sinking Feelings | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|14}} | ShortSummary = Wray visits Jack and finds only Jack's new assistant Faith ([[Alison Haislip]]) in the house. She tells him Jack is on his way to the airport and will call upon arriving in Las Vegas in half an hour. In the meantime, she invites Wray to play [[Marco Polo (game)|Marco Polo]] in the pool. As a reward for catching her, she tells him that Jack is planning to make a ''Spectrum'' movie with the original cast. Wray is devastated and tells her that he hates ''Spectrum''. She encourages him to tell Jack, but Jack loves ''Spectrum'' more than anyone. Jack calls, and because Wray does not want to talk to Jack, he leaves to go to the store opening. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | EpisodeNumber2 = 10 | Title = Thank You for Your Service | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|14}} | ShortSummary = The comics store owner Casey Wingwall ([[Seth Green]]) has Wray, [[Michael Dorn]] (himself), and [[Kevin Grevioux]] (himself) sit on a panel about overcoming racist stereotypes and bigotry. Upon learning Michael and Kevin become murderously angry at racist stereotypes, Wray attempts to gloss over his work on ''Wassup, Bitch?'', but Bobbie showcases samples of the characters. Because she does not have a voice sample of Rigamarole, Michael and Kevin force Wray to perform an excerpt of ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' in Rigamarole's voice. Wray's assistant Marion (J. Doc Farrow) helps Wray escape. Marion, a fan of ''Wassup, Bitch?'' because it helped him while he served as a [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] in [[Kabul]], does not feel it racist and asks Wray to perform more lines. However, one line causes Marion to doubt his initial assessment. Wray escapes with Bobbie before Marion can open the door for Michael and Kevin. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | EpisodeNumber2 = 11 | Title = Full Release | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|21}} | ShortSummary = Wray has a stress dream with his former co-stars confronting him on the set of ''Spectrum'', including Dawn ([[Amy Acker]]) with whom he has history & Stutter ([[Henry Rollins]]) who's still angry for "outing" him. He wakes to Jack (via phone) and Bobbie (surprisingly in person sitting at the foot of his bed, having broken into his apartment) telling him the incomplete "lost episode" of ''Spectrum'' has been released by the show's creator on Dutch television and is now available online. Jack has asked all the cast over for a reunion viewing party, but they decide to start watching the episode online with Dale ([[Jack Donner]]), Wray's drunk, elderly landlord & retired "stunt ladyman". Wray's laptop battery dies, so he decides to head over the Jack's, despite Bobbie and Dale's misgivings about him possibly hooking up with the now-married Dawn. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | EpisodeNumber2 = 12 | Title = Found and Lost | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|21}} | ShortSummary = Most of the ''Spectrum'' cast have reunited at Jack's to watch the "lost episode" which has been completed using animation, shadow puppets, and Dutch "lookalike" actors ([[James Gunn]] & [[Candice Patton]]) intercut with the existing but incomplete original footage. On the way to a meeting having bailed on the party at his own house, Jack video calls everyone to talk about doing a ''Spectrum'' movie. He's pulled over by a cop ([[Michael Trucco]]) who turns out to be a fan and lets him go after a photo op. Wray finally arrives, Stutter disappears leaving behind a threatening note, and Dawn starts to throw herself at Wray but is interrupted by Faith coming to Wray's rescue. They restart the show & then notice both Wray and Stutter are now missing and hear sounds of a struggle from another room. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | EpisodeNumber2 = 13 | Title = Too Much Closure for Comfort | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|10|21}} | ShortSummary = Stutter has Wray held captive in Jack's closet, confronting Wray as to why he outed him as a Republican. Faith once again steps in and rescues Wray. While trying to wash up after Stutter's spray cheese bomb goes off in his face, Wray has some uninvited one-on-one time some of the other reunion guests in Jack's bathroom. Brenda ([[Liza Lapira]]) tries to get him to say yes to the project so she can use the money to pay her debts from a sponsorship deal gone awry. Tiffany ([[Skyler Day]]) gives some unintentionally good advice. Dawn jumps Wray in Jack's bathtub. Meanwhile, Jack calls the party back and tells them that he has secured the rights and the ''Spectrum'' movie is a go. | LineColor = A5C6E0 }} }} === Season 2 (2016–17) === {{Episode table |background=#EFDF2B |overall=5 |season=5 |title=23 |director=14 |writer=33 |airdate=20 |released=y |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = What Goes Up... | DirectedBy = [[Alan Tudyk]] | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|8}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = New Deal, No Deal | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Nicholas Daly Clarke & Sean Bury | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|8}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = Them's the Breaks | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|15}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 17 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = A Small Step for Manly | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Nicholas Daly Clarke & Sean Bury | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|15}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 18 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = Dick Lansing | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|22}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 19 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = Gum Drop | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Sean Bury & Nicholas Daly Clark | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|12|22}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 20 | EpisodeNumber2 = 7 | Title = Pin Cushion | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|12}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 21 | EpisodeNumber2 = 8 | Title = I'm with Stupid | DirectedBy = Alan Tudyk | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Sean Bury & Nicholas Daly Clark | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|12}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 22 | EpisodeNumber2 = 9 | Title = Back to the Past | DirectedBy = Anthony Leonardi | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|19}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 23 | EpisodeNumber2 = 10 | Title = Dawn of Girth | DirectedBy = Anthony Leonardi | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Sean Bury & Nicholas Daly Clark | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|19}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 24 | EpisodeNumber2 = 11 | Title = A Shot with Finley | DirectedBy = Anthony Leonardi | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Sean Bury & Nicholas Daly Clark | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|26}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 25 | EpisodeNumber2 = 12 | Title = Shock to the System | DirectedBy = Anthony Leonardi | WrittenBy = Alan Tudyk and Josh Dean | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|26}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = EFDF2B }} }} == Production == === Conception and development === Tudyk developed the series based on his experiences as an actor touring the science fiction convention circuit. Though it is not autobiographical, the fictional ''Spectrum'' echoes ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'', a canceled science fiction series-turned-cult hit that starred Tudyk as a pilot and Fillion as a captain, and Wray's experiences draw heavily on incidents and people Tudyk and Fillion encountered at conventions.{{cite web|title=''Firefly'' stars launch Indiegogo campaign for web series ''Con Man'': 'It's the quickest way to see us back on a spaceship'|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/03/10/firefly-stars-nathan-fillion-and-alan-tudyk-launch-indiegogo-campaign-web-series|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|first=Clark|last=Collins|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Interview: Alan Tudyk and Nathan Fillion on comic-cons and their new webseries 'Con Men'|url=http://www.hitfix.com/harpy/interview-alan-tudyk-and-nathan-fillion-on-comic-cons-and-their-new-webseries-con-men|work=[[HitFix]]|first=Donna|last=Dickens|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} ''Spectrum'' is based on a prequel novel to ''[[The Softwire]]'' series currently being written by [[PJ Haarsma]], who is also a producer of ''Con Man''.{{cite web|title=Nathan Fillion and Alan Tudyk on "Con Man": We can't wait to get started|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/nathan-fillion-and-alan-tudyk-on-con-man-we-cant-wait-to-get-started/|work=[[CBS]]|first=Lauren|last=Moraski|date=March 17, 2015|accessdate=March 17, 2015}} Tudyk said in March 2015 that the concept had been in development for two years.{{cite web|last1=McCarthy|first1=Mike|title=Exclusive Interview: Alan Tudyk Talks ‘Con Man’ And ‘Firefly’|url=http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/2015/03/25/exclusive-interview-alan-tudyk-talks-con-man-and-firefly/|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=The Hollywood News|date=March 25, 2015}} He pitched the idea to a production company, which became interested in producing the series and began to draw up contracts. However, the company's funder left the company, and the series was dropped.{{cite web|title=7 Things You Need To Know About Nathan Fillion And Alan Tudyk’s New Web Series|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/keelyflaherty/things-you-need-to-know-about-nathan-fillion-and-alan-tudy|work=[[BuzzFeed]]|first=Keely|last=Flaherty|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} Tudyk spent a year meeting with producers but was disappointed. When asked to find an audience beyond "weird convention nerds," he refused, believing it to be compromising the concept of ''Con Man'' and disrespecting fans.{{cite web|title=Alan Tudyk on new web series Con Man and why he loves his fans|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/interviews/a634986/alan-tudyk-on-new-web-series-con-man-and-why-he-loves-his-fans.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Morgan|last=Jeffrey|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} The series premiered on September 30, 2015, on [[Vimeo]], with the first season consisting of 13 episodes. The second season premiered on December 8, 2016 on Comic-Con HQ, Comic-Con's subscription streaming video service, consisted of 12 episodes, and concluded on January 26, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.blastr.com/2016-5-6/alan-tudyks-web-series-con-man-gets-new-home-season-2|title=Alan Tudyk's web series Con Man gets a new home for Season 2|work=[[Blastr]]|first=Aaron|last=Sagers|date=May 6, 2016|accessdate=July 3, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2016/11/30/comic-con-hq-streaming-service-con-man-season-2-trailer|title=Check out Alan Tudyk, Nathan Fillion in new trailer for Comic Con HQ series 'Con Man'|work=Mashable|first=Saba|last=Hamedy|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=December 1, 2016}} In July 2017, the series was acquired by [[Syfy]] and had its television debut on September 9, 2017. The web series was shown as is but the episodes were combined to produce half-hour installments for airing, with all thirteen episodes of the first season aired back-to-back on the night.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/happy-premiere-date-syfy-superstition-ghost-wars-z-nation-van-helsing-1202156371/ |title=Syfy Sets Premiere Dates For New Series ‘Happy!’, ‘Superstition’ & ‘Ghost Wars’ Along With Returning Shows |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |first=Erik |last=Pedersen |date=August 25, 2017 |accessdate=September 9, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/07/syfy-con-man-broadcast-september-1201858456/ |title=Syfy Acquires 'Con Man,' Adding Alan Tudyk's Emmy-Nominated Indie Comedy To Its Lineup — Exclusive |website=[[IndieWire]] |date=July 21, 2017 |first=Liz Shannon |last=Miller}} If the reception of the television network broadcast goes well and viewer ratings are sufficient, the network may decide to fund future seasons. === Crowdfunding campaign === On March 10, 2015, Tudyk, Fillion, and Haarsma launched a campaign to raise funds for the series on crowdfunding website [[Indiegogo]] with a target goal of $425,000 to produce three ten-minute episodes. In 24 hours, the campaign raised over $1 million, setting a one-day record for a crowdfunded web series.{{cite web|title=‘Con Man’ Web Series From Nathan Fillion And Alan Tudyk Smashing Crowdfunding Records|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/browncoats-give-1-6-million-for-fillion-tudyk-web-series-1201392389/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Ross|last=Lincoln|date=March 13, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2015}} In 35 hours, it raised over $1.4 million, breaking the overall web series crowdfunding record set by the campaign for ''[[TableTop (web series)|TableTop]]''{{'}}s Season Three.{{cite web|title=Alan Tudyk & Nathan Fillion's 'Con Man' breaks crowdfunding record|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/tudyk-and-fillions-con-man-breaks-crowdfunding-record/5084231.article|work=[[ScreenDaily.com]]|first=Ian|last=Sandwell|date=March 13, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Not-Exactly- ‘Firefly’ Comedy Sequel Nears a Crowdfunding Record|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/03/12/not-exactly-firefly-comedy-sequel-nears-a-crowdfunding-record/|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|first=Don|last=Steinberg|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}{{cite web|title=‘Firefly’ Alums Nathan Fillion, Alan Tudyk Shatter Indiegogo Record by Raising $1 Million in Less Than 24 Hours|url=http://www.thewrap.com/firefly-alums-nathan-fillion-alan-tudyk-shatter-indiegogo-record-by-raising-1-million-in-less-than-24-hours/|work=[[TheWrap]]|first=Matt|last=Donnelly|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} The campaign set a stretch goal of $1.75 million to produce a full season of 12 episodes, as Tudyk planned, plus a "lost" episode of the fictional ''Spectrum''.{{cite web|title='Firefly's' Nathan Fillion, Alan Tudyk reunite for 'Con Man' Web series|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-firefly-fillion-tudyk-reunite-con-man-web-series-20150313-story.html|work=[[LA Times]]|first=Patrick Kevin|last=Day|date=March 13, 2015|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} The goal was met on March 14, 2015.{{cite web|title=PJ Haarsma on Twitter: "1.7 Wow! We are making the whole thing! #conman"|url=https://twitter.com/PJhaarsma/status/576623522967093248|work=[[Twitter]]|date=March 14, 2015|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} The campaign closed on April 10, 2015 with $3,124,214.{{cite web|title=Con Man | Indiegogo|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/con-man|work=[[Indiegogo]]|accessdate=April 11, 2015}} The decision to use crowdfunding came out of Tudyk and Fillion's desire to work with people who knew the world of conventions, would enjoy being involved, and did not disrespect fans and their world. Tudyk said, "It's something that just made sense. This world of Cons, of the sci-fi conventions, is built by the fans."{{cite web|title = Alan Tudyk and Nathan Fillion launch Indiegogo Campaign for Con Man|url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/11/alan-tudyk-and-nathan-fillion-launch-indiegogo-campaign-for-con-man|work = [[IGN]]|first = Matt|last = Fowler|date = March 11, 2015|accessdate = March 13, 2015}} Fillion said, "This project in the hands of the fans is the only place it will be safe." === Casting === The launch of crowdfunding campaign announced that it would be drawing from talent in science fiction and named several guest stars: [[Seth Green]], [[Felicia Day]], [[James Gunn (filmmaker)|James Gunn]], [[Gina Torres]], [[Sean Maher]], and [[Amy Acker]]. Later, [[Tricia Helfer]], [[Michael Trucco]], [[Nolan North]], [[Emily Kinney]], [[Robert Patrick]], [[Mindy Sterling]], and [[Samantha Smith (actress)|Samantha Smith]] were announced as cast members.{{Cite web|url = http://nerdist.com/exclusive-seven-more-stars-announced-for-alan-tudyk-and-nathan-fillions-web-series-con-man/|title = Exclusive: Seven More Stars Announced for Alan Tudyk and Nathan Fillion’s Web Series|date = March 30, 2015|accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = [[Nerdist Industries|The Nerdist]]|publisher = |last = McCabe|first = Joseph}} However, Kinney later left the project because filming dates conflicted with her musical tour.{{Cite web|url = https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/3nlnro/iama_singersongwriteractor_emily_kinney_ama/cvp6b0r|title = IamA Singer/songwriter-Actor, Emily Kinney! AMA!|date = October 5, 2015|accessdate = October 12, 2015|website = |publisher = [[Reddit]]|last = |first = }} Though the crew thought they would be "begging for favors" to cast the series, the successful Indiegogo campaign attracted interest from actors, including [[William Shatner]],{{Cite web|url = http://www.slugmag.com/articles/9639/Uncancellable-Alan-Tudyk-and-Nathan-Fillions-Con-Men.html|title = Uncancellable: Alan Tudyk and Nathan Fillion's Con Man|date = March 20, 2015|accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = [[SLUG Magazine]]|publisher = |last = Lippert|first = Ashley}} and the crew was surprised by the willingness to take small parts. Fillion noted, "We ran out of parts before we ran out of people for the parts."{{Cite web|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/09/30/firefly-stars-alan-tudyk-nathan-fillion-ready-con-man-web-series/|title = ‘Firefly’ Stars Alan Tudyk, Nathan Fillion Ready ‘Con Man’ Web Series|date = September 30, 2015|accessdate = October 12, 2015|website = |publisher = ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|last = Steinberg|first = Don}} Tudyk stated that some actors appear as fictionalized versions of themselves because "they are a part of that world." In June 2016, it was announced that [[Eliza Dushku]] had been cast for the second season.{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/06/16/con-man-eliza-dushku-alan-tudyk |title=Eliza Dushku, Alan Tudyk reunite for ''Con Man'' season 2 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |first=Evan |last=Slead |date=June 16, 2016 |accessdate=July 3, 2016}} === Filming === [[Principal photography]] for the first season ran over a 23-day period from June 1 to 30, 2015, in [[Los Angeles]].{{cite interview |last1= Tudyk|first1= Alan|subjectlink1= Alan Tudyk|last2=Haarsma|first2=PJ|subjectlink2=PJ Haarsma|interviewer=[[Bill Carroll (broadcaster)|Bill Carroll]]|title= Local Filmmakers Make Big!|url= http://www.kfiam640.com/onair/bill-carroll-37820/local-filmmakers-make-big-13575978/|publisher= [[KFI]]|location= [[Los Angeles]]|date= May 8, 2015|work= The Bill Carroll Show|access-date=May 12, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Con Man on Twitter: "And that's a wrap on #conman . Thank you everyone! Cheers."|url=https://twitter.com/ConManSeries/status/616065689305022464|work=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=July 12, 2015|date=June 30, 2015}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.fastcocreate.com/3051619/how-con-man-rallied-geek-fans-and-defied-hollywood-convention|title = How "Con Man" Rallied Geek Fans And Defied Hollywood Convention|date = September 30, 2015|accessdate = October 12, 2015|website = |publisher = [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|last = Karlin|first = Susan}} The set was located at Laurel Canyon Stages in [[Arleta, Los Angeles]]. Some crowd scenes were shot at [[MegaCon]] 2015 in [[Orlando, Florida]] on April 10.{{cite web|last1=Edwards|first1=Debbie|title=Con Man News: AMA, Stretch Goals, Campaign Updates|url=http://www.geekynews.com/con-man-news-ama-stretch-goals-campaign-updates-76357/|website=GeekyNews|accessdate=April 12, 2015|date=April 8, 2015}} == Awards == The series received two 2017 [[Emmy Award]] nominations: Alan Tudyk for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series|Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series]] and Mindy Sterling for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Actress in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series|Outstanding Actress in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/866572/2017-emmy-nominations-complete-list-of-nominees|title=2017 Emmy Nominations: Complete List of Nominees|last=Johnson|first=Zach|date=July 13, 2017|work=|access-date=July 13, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=[[E!]]|last2=|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/emmys-verizons-go90-lionsgates-comic-con-hq-nab-noms-shortform-categories-1020815|title=Emmys: Verizon's Go90, Lionsgate's Comic-Con HQ Nab Noms in Short Form Categories|last=Jarvey|first=Natalie|date=July 13, 2017|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|access-date=July 13, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} == Notes == {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://conmantheseries.com/}} * {{Twitter|name=''Con Man''}} * {{IMDb title|tt4642170}} * [https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/con-man ''Con Man''] on [[Indiegogo]] * [http://www.syfy.com/conman ''Con Man''] on [[SyFy]] {{Syfy Shows|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:American web series]] [[Category:Crowdfunded web series]] [[Category:2015 web series debuts]]

{{Short description|American burlesque dancer, model and actress}} {{for|the Canadian politician|Heather Sweet (politician)}} {{Use American English|date=October 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Dita Von Teese |image = Dita Von Teese at Cannes 2007.jpg |caption = Von Teese at the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]] |birth_name = Heather Renée Sweet |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|9|28}} |birth_place = [[Rochester, Michigan]], U.S. |occupation = [[Neo-Burlesque|Burlesque dancer]], [[vedette (cabaret)|vedette]], model, [[costume designer]], author, actress, singer, entrepreneur |years_active = 1990–present |spouse = {{marriage|[[Marilyn Manson]]|2005|2007|reason=divorced}} |website = {{URL|http://www.dita.net/}} }}
'''Dita Von Teese''' (born '''Heather Renée Sweet''';<ref name=vonTeeseParis>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSTRE50L5IN20090122|title=Striptease queen Dita von Teese back at Paris revue|last=Mackenzie|first=James|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=January 22, 2009|accessdate=January 25, 2009}}</ref> September 28, 1972) is an American [[vedette (cabaret)|vedette]], [[American burlesque|burlesque]] dancer, model, costume designer, entrepreneur, singer, and actress.<ref name="Werle2009">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HiALAQAAMAAJ|title=Fashionista: A Century of Style Icons|year=2009|last=Werle|first=Simone|publisher=Prestel|page=170}}</ref> She is credited with re-popularizing burlesque performance, earning the moniker "Queen of Burlesque".<ref name="Willson2007">{{cite book|author=Willson, Jacki|title=The Happy Stripper: Pleasures and Politics of the New Burlesque|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTiP4-1O0bUC|date=December 15, 2007|accessdate=January 29, 2013|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-84511-318-6|page=14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/dita-von-teese-interview/|title=Dita Von Teese Interview: Queen of Burlesque Dishes on Her Debut|date=November 15, 2018|work=Highsnobiety|access-date=November 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/dita-von-teese-burlesque-feminism-name|title=Dita Von Teese on Burlesque Feminism, Nude Selfies, and How She Came Up With Her Name|work=Vogue|access-date=November 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/25/fashion/dita-von-teese-from-burlesque-to-a-brand.html|title=Dita Von Teese, From Burlesque to a Brand|last=Ferla|first=Ruth La|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 23, 2012|accessdate=November 15, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Von Teese was born in [[Rochester, Michigan]], the second of three daughters.<ref name="TimesNakAmb">{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/celebrity/article4757809.ece|title=Dita von Teese's naked ambition|last=McLean|first=Craig|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=September 20, 2008|accessdate=September 20, 2008}}</ref> Her father was a [[machinist]] and her mother a [[manicurist]].<ref name="TimesNakAmb"/><ref name="The Art of Teese">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2006/03/06/efdita04.xml|title=Art of the Teese|last=West|first=Naomi|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=June 3, 2006|accessdate=February 17, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911072009/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=%2Ffashion%2F2006%2F03%2F06%2Fefdita04.xml|archivedate=September 11, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> She is of [[English people|English]], [[Scottish people|Scottish]], [[Armenian people|Armenian]], and [[German people|German]] heritage.<ref>[https://twitter.com/DitaVonTeese/status/356816050005872642 Official Twitter]. Twitter.com (July 15, 2013). Retrieved on August 22, 2011.</ref> Dita has stated that one of her grandmothers was half-Armenian and adopted into an Anglo-Saxon American family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://style.news.am/eng/news/2804/my-grandmother-was-half-armenian---exclusive-interview-with-dita-von-teese.html|title=My grandmother was half Armenian – exclusive interview with Dita Von Teese|publisher=style.news.am|accessdate=February 10, 2013}}</ref> Von Teese is known for her fascination with [[1940s in film|1940s cinema]] and classic vintage style. This began at a young age and was fostered by her mother, who would buy clothes for her daughter to dress up. Her mother was a fan of old, [[Cinema of the United States#Golden Age of Hollywood|Golden Age-era Hollywood films]], and from her Von Teese developed a fascination with the actresses of that day, especially [[Betty Grable]].
She was classically trained as a ballet dancer from an early age, and danced solo at age 13 for a local ballet company. Though she originally wanted to be a [[ballerina]], Von Teese states that "by 15, I was as good as I'd ever be."<ref name="The Art of Teese"/> She was later to incorporate this element into her burlesque shows, where she frequently goes ''[[en pointe]]''. The family relocated from Michigan to [[Orange County, California]], when her father's job moved.<ref name="TimesNakAmb"/> Von Teese attended [[University High School (Irvine, California)|University High School]] in [[Irvine, California]].<ref name="ocregister">{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/features/lifestyle/article_1086656.php|title=Dita Von Teese: Call her old-fashioned|last=Nguyen|first=Katherine|work=[[Orange County Register]]|date=April 6, 2006|accessdate=February 17, 2007}}</ref>
When Von Teese was a teenager, her mother took her to buy her first [[bra]], made from plain white cotton, and gave her a plastic egg containing a pair of wrinkly, flesh-colored [[pantyhose]].<ref name=ocregister/> Von Teese says she was disappointed, as she had been hoping to receive beautiful lacy garments and stockings, of the type she had glimpsed in her father's ''[[Playboy]]'' magazines. This fueled her passion for lingerie. She worked in a lingerie store as a salesgirl when she was 15, eventually as a [[buyer]]. Von Teese has been fond of wearing elaborate lingerie such as [[corset]]s and [[Basque (clothing)|basques]] with [[fully fashioned stockings]] ever since. In college, Von Teese studied historic [[costuming]] and aspired to work as a [[Wardrobe stylist|stylist]] for films. She is a trained [[costume designer]], often designing (and [[copyright]]ing) her photo shoots herself.<ref name=burlesqueisback>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/theater/160251_burlesque12.html|title=Burlesque is Back|last=Dizon|first=Kristen|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|date=February 12, 2004|accessdate=March 24, 2007}}</ref>
==Career== Von Teese chose her stage name by adopting the name Dita as a tribute to silent film actress [[Dita Parlo]]. For her breakthrough December 2002 ''Playboy'' cover, she was required to have a surname, so she chose ''Von Treese'' from the phonebook. ''Playboy'' misspelled it ''Von Teese'', a name which she then kept.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/von-143092-teese-burlesque.html|title=Dita Von Teese: Call her old-fashioned|last=Nguyen|first=Katherine|work=The Orange County Register|publisher=Orange County Register Communications|date=April 5, 2006|accessdate=September 2, 2012}}</ref>
===Fetish and glamour modeling=== Von Teese achieved some level of recognition in the fetish world as a [[tightlacer]]. Through the wearing of a [[corset]] for many years, she had reduced her waistline to {{convert|22|in|cm}}, and can be laced down as far as {{convert|16.5|in|cm}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/more-teese-if-you-please-1-2076457|title=More Teese if you please|work=Yorkshire Evening Post|date=October 20, 2006|accessdate=September 15, 2018}}</ref>
Von Teese appeared on a number of [[fetish magazine]] covers, including ''[[Bizarre (magazine)|Bizarre]]''<ref name="Bizarre Magazine">{{cite web|url=http://www.bizarremag.com/bizarre_girls/cover_girls/7221/dita_von_teese.html|title=Viva La Dita!|last=Hodges|first=Kate|publisher=Dennis Publishing|date=July 6, 2008|accessdate=February 17, 2007}}</ref> and ''[[Marquis (magazine)|Marquis]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dita.net/credits.php |title=Dita Von Teese – Credits and Appearances |website=Dita.net |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930140032/http://www.dita.net/credits.php |deadurl=yes}}</ref> It was around this time when she appeared on the cover of [[Midori (author)|Midori]]'s book, ''The Seductive Art of Japanese Bondage''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomshub.com/top-influential-lingerie-models-and-fitness-babes/|title=These are top most influential lingerie models and Fitness Babes!|last=Peter|first=Max|website=Bloomshub|date=February 26, 2018|accessdate=April 2, 2018}}</ref> Von Teese was featured in ''Playboy'' in 1999, 2001, and 2002, with a cover-featured pictorial in 2002. The German [[Heavy metal music|metal]] band [[Atrocity (band)|Atrocity]] chose her as the cover model for their 2008 album, ''[[Werk 80 II]]''.<ref>[http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=26469_0_2_1_C Ex-Marilyn Manson featured on Atrocity cover]. Side-line.com (February 22, 1999). Retrieved on August 22, 2011.</ref>
She has stated in print, "I love fetish for its powers of transformation and also for its beauty." Among her heroes of vintage fetish history are [[John Willie]], [[Bettie Page]], and [[Irving Klaw]].<ref>''Burlesque and the Art of the Teese: Fetish and the Art of the Teese'' New York: Regan Books, 2006, p. xv.</ref>
===Burlesque=== [[File:SDG Von Teese 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Von Teese is a prominent Neo-Burlesque performer]] Von Teese is best known for her burlesque routines and is frequently dubbed the "Queen of Burlesque" in the press.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion/show_coverage/2007/2007_2008_rafw_spring_summer/the_buzz/dita_von_teese_my_fashion_life|title=My Fashion Life: Dita Von Teese|last=Maynard|first=Melissa|work=Vogue Australia|date=June 1, 2005|accessdate=May 25, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503164544/http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion/show_coverage/2007/2007_2008_rafw_spring_summer/the_buzz/dita_von_teese_my_fashion_life|archivedate=May 3, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factio-magazine.com/womanofstyle/des_DitaVonTeese.cfm |title=Woman of Global Style: Dita Von Teese |accessdate=March 20, 2007 |author=Créac'h, Isabelle-Marie |work=Vogue |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309154648/http://www.factio-magazine.com/womanofstyle/des_DitaVonTeese.cfm |archivedate=March 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Von Teese began performing burlesque in 1992, and, as a proponent of [[Neo-Burlesque]], has helped to popularize its revival.<ref name=suicidegirls>{{cite web|url=http://tribes.tribe.net/ditavonteese/thread/43c6a563-9800-4960-aae2-712e76956a9e|title=Suicide Girls Interview|accessdate=March 19, 2007|author=Epstein, Daniel Robert|date=March 10, 2006|work=Tribe.net|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323020244/http://tribes.tribe.net/ditavonteese/thread/43c6a563-9800-4960-aae2-712e76956a9e|archivedate=March 23, 2017}}</ref> In her own words, she "puts the [[teasing|tease]] back into [[striptease]]" with long, elaborate dance shows with props and characters, often inspired by 1930s and 1940s musicals and films. Some of her more famous dances have involved a [[carousel]] horse, a giant powder compact, a filigree heart and a [[Slipper Bathtub|clawfoot bathtub]] with a working shower head. Her signature show features a giant [[Martini (cocktail)|martini]] glass. Her feather [[fan dance]], inspired by burlesque dancer [[Sally Rand]], featured the world's largest feather fans, now on display in Hollywood's [[Sex museum|Museum of Sex]].<ref name="burlesque">{{cite web|url=http://www.dita.net/shows.php |title=Dita Von Teese – Shows and Performances |website=Dita.net |accessdate=May 28, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528193017/http://www.dita.net/shows.php#showsgallery |archivedate=May 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Her burlesque career has included some memorable performances. She once appeared at a benefit for the [[New York Academy of Art]] wearing nothing but $5 million worth of diamonds.<ref name="diamonds">[http://www.queerty.com/diamonds-are-a-queens-best-friend-20051018/ Diamonds Are a Queen's Best Friend], ''Queerty'', October 18, 2005. Retrieved on November 5, 2011.</ref> Additionally, Von Teese became the first guest star at Paris's [[Crazy Horse (cabaret)|Crazy Horse]] cabaret club with her appearance in October 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lecrazyhorseparis.com/en/guest-star/3124/|title=Dita Von Teese - Guest Star at the Crazy Horse Paris|work=Crazy Horse Paris|accessdate=April 2, 2018}}</ref> Also in 2006, Von Teese appeared on an episode of ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' (cycle 7) doing a workshop to teach the contestants about sexiness by means of burlesque dancing and posing. In 2007, Von Teese performed at the adult entertainment event Erotica 07 in London alongside Italian [[rock music|rock]] band [[Belladonna (band)|Belladonna]].
Von Teese's first book (in collaboration with Bronwyn Garrity), which consisted of her opinions on the history of burlesque and fetish, ''Burlesque and the Art of the Teese / Fetish and the Art of the Teese'', was published in 2006 by [[HarperCollins]] (and in New York by Regan Books). ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' called her a "Burlesque Superheroine".
Von Teese participated in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] in Moscow, Russia, as part of the stage performance for the [[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009|German]] entry "[[Miss Kiss Kiss Bang]]". The act placed 20th out of 25 participants in the final round of the contest.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090502173421/http://esctoday.com/news/read/13830 Burlesque star in German line-up]. Esctoday.com. Retrieved on August 22, 2011.</ref> Later, she said her cleavage was censored during the show because it was too voluptuous.<ref>[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a180160/teese-eurovision-censors-picked-on-me.html Von Teese: 'Eurovision censors picked on me' – Showbiz News]. Digital Spy (October 2, 2009). Retrieved on August 22, 2011. She has just wrapped up her 2012 tour of "Strip Strip Hooray", where she performed some of her famously known acts such as "a Guy who takes his time", Compact act, Cowgirl act, and her famous Japanese-inspired act.</ref>
==Acting== Von Teese has performed in adult and mainstream films. In her early years, she appeared in fetish-related, [[soft-core]] pornographic movies, such as ''Romancing Sara,'' ''Matter of Trust'' (in which she is billed under her real name of Heather Sweet), and also in two [[Andrew Blake (director)|Andrew Blake]] [[Hardcore pornography|hard-core]] fetish films, ''Pin Ups 2''<ref>[http://www.thenewsvault.com/cgi/news.pl?t=1359 Dita Von Teese Lesbian Sex Video Surfaces]. Thenewsvault.com. Retrieved on August 22, 2011.</ref> and ''Decadence.''
In recent years, she has appeared in more mainstream features, such as the 2005 short film, ''[[The Death of Salvador Dali]]'', written by Delaney Bishop, which won best screenplay and best [[cinematography]] at [[SXSW]], [[Raindance Film Festival]], and [[Mill Valley Film Festival]], and won Best Actress at [[Beverly Hills Film Festival]]. She starred in the feature film ''Saint Francis'' in 2007.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0437363/ Saint Francis (2007)]. IMDb.com.</ref>
In addition, she has appeared in a number of music videos, including the video for the [[Green Day]] song "[[Redundant (song)|Redundant]],"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greendayauthority.com/TheBand/didjaknow.php?section=all |title=Didja Know: Useless Green Day facts |accessdate=February 17, 2007 |work=The Green Day Authority |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309154648/http://www.factio-magazine.com/womanofstyle/des_DitaVonTeese.cfm |archivedate=March 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> the video for "Zip Gun Bop" by [[Swing music|swing]] band [[Royal Crown Revue]], [[Agent Provocateur (lingerie)|Agent Provocateur]]'s video for their cover of [[Joy Division]]'s "[[She's Lost Control]]," and (performing her martini-glass burlesque routine) the video for "[[Mobscene]]" by Marilyn Manson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playboy.com/arts-entertainment/celebphoto/marilynmanson/index.html|title=Sweet (wet) dreams are Made of this: Marilyn Manson snaps nudes of modern-day fetish queen/girlfriend Dita von Teese|last=Fischer|first=Blair R.|work=[[Playboy]]|accessdate=February 17, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306014948/http://www.playboy.com/arts-entertainment/celebphoto/marilynmanson/index.html|archivedate=March 6, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> She was featured in a striptease/burlesque act in [[George Michael]]'s live tour 2008, for the song "Feelin' Good".<ref>{{YouTube|id=_iT-oweszAI|title=Dita von Teese and George Michael live in Madison Square Garden}}.</ref> In addition to this, she appeared at the final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] as the central feature of [[Germany]]'s entry, [[Miss Kiss Kiss Bang]] by [[Alex Swings, Oscar Sings]]. She also appeared in the music video "[[Up in the Air (song)|Up in the Air]]" by [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]] in 2013.
She stated in 2007, "I don't understand why women feel the need to go into acting as soon as they become famous ... But I suppose if the part were aesthetically correct, then maybe I could consider it."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml?xml=/opinion/2006/02/18/dp1801.xml|title=Spy: Not an Act|last=Isaby|first=Jonathan|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=February 18, 2006|accessdate=May 27, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025075547/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fopinion%2F2006%2F02%2F18%2Fdp1801.xml|archivedate=October 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
In January 2011, Von Teese guest-starred in the [[CBS]] police procedural drama series ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'', in which her friend [[Eric Szmanda]] starred, in the episode "[[A Kiss Before Frying]]." She played Rita von Squeeze, a [[femme fatale]] version of herself, who seduces Szmanda's character, [[Greg Sanders]], in a plot inspired by [[film noir]].<ref>[http://www.tv.com/shows/csi-crime-scene-investigation/a-kiss-before-frying-1364685/ A Kiss Before Frying]. TV.com. Retrieved on February 11, 2014.</ref>
==Fashion and modeling== [[File:Dita Von Teese Heart Truth 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Von Teese on the catwalk at [[The Heart Truth]] in February 2011]] Von Teese has appeared on a number of best-dressed lists<ref>[http://www.factio-magazine.com/profiles/detail.cfm?article_id=13021837 Dita Von Teese] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060548/http://www.factio-magazine.com/profiles/detail.cfm?article_id=13021837|date=March 4, 2016}}, ''Factio Magazine''. Accessed November 5, 2011.</ref> and frequents the front row of fashion shows, particularly [[Christian Dior]], [[Vivienne Westwood]], [[Jean Paul Gaultier]], and [[Marc Jacobs]], labels she is often seen wearing. Speaking of her love of Gaultier, Von Teese has said, "Jean Paul Gaultier, John Galliano, and Vivienne Westwood were the first designers that really made an impact on me. Jean Paul has a lot of the same obsessions that I do, like corsetry, ballet-peach satin and silks, black silk velvet, bullet bras and girdles. When I was a teenager, I would look for 1930s peach satin lingerie pieces to try to get his look for less, because there was no way I could afford his things back then. It was a dream come true to meet him and become friends with him. I met him the first time when I was doing my first fashion pictorial, which was for Flaunt magazine, and it was a huge story of me wearing the most important pieces from his haute couture archives, and that was a dream!" <ref>[http://www.realstylenetwork.com/Magazine/Winter2013/#/28/ Real Style Magazine – Winter 2013]. Realstylenetwork.com. Retrieved on February 11, 2014.</ref>
She has also done [[catwalk]] work. During [[Los Angeles Fashion Week]] for spring 2004, she modeled for former [[club kid]] [[Richie Rich (designer)|Richie Rich]]'s fashion label, [[Heatherette]]. In 2005, she appeared in the Autumn/Winter Ready-to-Wear show for Giambattista Valli, a former designer for [[Ungaro]], in Paris. In the 2006 [[Milan Fashion Week]], Von Teese was on the runway, opening for the Moschino diffusion label, Moschino Cheap & Chic, autumn/winter 2006/7 show. In 2007, she appeared twice in the [[Jean Paul Gaultier]] [[haute couture]] show during the [[Paris Fashion Week]], and again in 2014. She has starred in several ad campaigns. She appeared in [[Vivienne Westwood]]'s spring/summer 2005 collection adverts and became the face of Australian clothing range "Wheels and Dollbaby" for their 2006/7 Spring/Summer advertising campaign. She was an ambassador/spokesmodel for HIV/AIDS awareness when she was selected (along with [[Eve (entertainer)|Eve]], [[Deborah Harry]], and [[Lisa Marie Presley]]) for [[MAC Cosmetics]]' Viva Glam VI campaign (a collection of lipsticks and lipgloss where 100% of the proceeds are for worldwide AIDS charities and to raise awareness for HIV/AIDS). Von Teese has appeared in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|author=Väisänen, Annika Suvi Johanna|title=Dita Von Teesen Tyylivinkit|journal=Elle Finland|date=January 2009}}</ref> and international issues of nearly every fashion magazine. She has campaigned on behalf of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) and has appeared in their ads. She participated at the [[PETA]]'s campaign "Animal Birth Control (ABC)."<ref>[http://www.helpinganimals.com/f-dita-von-teese.asp Dita] for Peta's ABC campaign.</ref>
Von Teese states that she never uses a stylist. "The one time I hired a stylist, they picked up a pair of my 1940s shoes and said, 'These would look really cute with jeans.' I immediately said, 'You’re out of here.'" She does her own make-up, and dyes her naturally blonde hair black at home.<ref name="The Art of Teese"/> Von Teese's unique style is "inspired by eccentric women like [[Luisa Casati]], [[Anna Piaggi]], and [[Isabella Blow]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.venuszine.com/articles/fashion/features/2670/Dita_Von_Teese_the_showgirl |title=Dita Von Teese the Showgirl |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |author1=Schroeder, Amy |author2=Han, Constanze Lyndsay |date=December 1, 2007 |work=Venuszine.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824115515/http://www.venuszine.com/articles/fashion/features/2670/Dita_Von_Teese_the_showgirl |archivedate=August 24, 2009 }}</ref>
She has designed a new lingerie range with [[Wonderbra]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1576152/Dita-von-Teese-named-new-Wonderbra-model.html|title=Dita von Teese named new Wonderbra model|work=The Telegraph|date=January 21, 2008|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> One of Dita Von Teese's trademark items is the garter belt with six garters instead of the usual four, with two each at the front, side seams and back.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.herroom.com/dita-von-teese.shtml|title=Dita Von Teese at HerRoom}}</ref> In May 2012, Dita Von Teese launched her makeup collection "Classics" in partnership with the German cosmetic brand Art Deco. Compact powder, blushers, eye styler, eye shadows, mascara and lipstick were produced to recreate the burlesque performer's retro look.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moodiereport.com/document.php?c_id=33&doc_id=30846|title=Dita Von Teese to release first makeup collection with Artdeco|last=Ng|first=Melody|work=Moodie Report |date=April 27, 2012|accessdate=May 4, 2012}}</ref>
In 2012, Dita Von Teese launched her own clothing line<ref name=Alexander2012>{{cite web|last=Alexander|first=Ella|title=Dita Von Teese On Dresses Collection|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2012/12/10/dita-von-teese-dresses-collection---pictures-and-interview|date=December 10, 2012|work=Vogue|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref> and underwear line called Von Follies.<ref name=Ella2012Nov>{{cite web|last=Alexander|first=Ella|title=Dita Von Teese Lingerie Exclusive|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2012/11/30/dita-von-teese-von-follies-lingerie-uk-launch|date=November 30, 2012|work=Vogue|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Ella2012March>{{cite web|last=Alexander|first=Ella|title=Lingerie Teese|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2011/11/22/dita-von-teese-launches-lingerie-label|date=March 9, 2012|work=Vogue|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref> In 2013, Dita was both model and muse for the 'Dita' [[3D printed]] gown designed by Michael Schmidt and Francis Bitonti and 3D printed by [[Shapeways]] exactly to fit her body.<ref>[http://www.shapeways.com/blog/archives/1952-Revealing-Dita-Von-Teese-in-a-Fully-Articulated-3D-Printed-Gown.html Revealing Dita Von Teese in a Fully Articulated 3D Printed Gown – Shapeways Blog on 3D Printing News & Innovation]. Shapeways.com (March 5, 2013). Retrieved on February 11, 2014.</ref> Constructed of over 3,000 interlocked 3D printed components and over 12,000 [[Swarovski]] crystals it is one of the first fully articulated 3D printed garments to take the technology from haute couture to a sensual fabric-like form.<ref>Shapiro, David. (March 5, 2013) [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324678604578342570070411796 The Dimensions of Design – WSJ.com]. Online.wsj.com. Retrieved on February 11, 2014.</ref>
In 2014, Von Teese began working with [[Myer]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2731615/Myer-spices-spring-summer-parading-SEXY-new-lingerie-looks-Dita-Von-Teese-Sass-Bide.html|title =Daily Mail Article on Von Teese and Myer|accessdate=March 30, 2015|author=Penelope Kilby|work=Daily Mail Australia|location=Australia}}</ref> an Australian department store, on a lingerie line fronted by Australian [[Model (people)|model]] [[Stefania Ferrario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mic.com/articles/113498/this-aussie-model-s-drop-the-plus-campaign-proves-that-size-is-just-a-number|title=Stefania Ferrario mic.com article |publisher=Mic.com|accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Von Teese frequently takes [[Pilates]] and [[dressage]] lessons. Her house is dedicated to early 20th-century décor, including a complete pink kitchen with vintage appliances. She also has a room dedicated to hats.<ref name="TimesNakAmb"/>
Von Teese currently resides in [[Hollywood|Hollywood, California]].<ref name=EducaDita>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2007/04/22/stdita122.xml&page=3 |title=Educating Dita |accessdate=April 22, 2007 |author=Cutter, Kimberly |date=April 22, 2007 |work=The Sunday Telegraph |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426041441/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=%2Ffashion%2F2007%2F04%2F22%2Fstdita122.xml&page=3 |archivedate=April 26, 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.suicidegirls.com/girls/nicole_powers/blog/2680187/dita-von-teese-stripteese/|title=Dita Von Teese: Stripteese|website=[[SuicideGirls.com]]|date=December 18, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}</ref> She is a collector of vintage china, particularly [[egg cup]]s and [[tea set]]s,<ref name=vintage>{{cite web|url=http://www.exposay.com/ditas-vinage-obsession/v/7159/ |title=Dita's Vintage Obsession |accessdate=March 24, 2007 |website=exposay.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401020154/http://www.exposay.com/ditas-vinage-obsession/v/7159/ |archivedate=April 1, 2007 |date=December 27, 2006 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and drives a [[Packard One-Twenty|1939 Packard One Twenty Eight]], a 1946 [[1941 Ford|Ford Super De Luxe]],<ref>Johnson, Graham (November 2011) [http://www.heavy.com/moto/moto-video/2011/11/driving-with-dita-von-teese/ Driving With Dita Von Teese] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221153758/http://www.heavy.com/moto/moto-video/2011/11/driving-with-dita-von-teese/ |date=February 21, 2014 }}. heavy.com.</ref> a [[BMW Z4]] and a 1965 [[Jaguar S-Type (1963)|Jaguar S-Type]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dita.net/bio.php |title=Dita Von Teese – Biographical Information |website=Dita.net |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828120919/http://www.dita.net/bio.php |archivedate=August 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> She also owned a 1939 [[Chrysler New Yorker]] from 1997 to December 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.streetlegaltv.com/news/dita-von-teeses-1939-chrysler-new-yorker-sells-for-23403/|title=Dita Von Teese’s 1939 Chrysler New Yorker Sold For (3,403)|website=Streetlegaltv.com|date=December 23, 2010|accessdate=August 22, 2011}}</ref>
===Marriage to Marilyn Manson=== [[Marilyn Manson]] had been a longtime fan of hers and was a member of her website. They first met when he asked her to dance in one of his music videos, and though she was unable to, the two remained in contact. On Manson's 32nd birthday, in 2001,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1137134,00.html|title=Marilyn Manson Marries Girlfriend in Ireland|work= People|date=December 4, 2005|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> she arrived with a bottle of [[absinthe]] and they became a couple. Manson proposed on March 22, 2004, and gave her a 1930s, {{convert|7|carat|g|adj=on}}, European round-cut diamond engagement ring. On November 28, 2005, they were married in a private, non-denominational ceremony at home. A larger ceremony was held on December 3 at [[Castle Gurteen de la Poer]] in [[Kilsheelan]] ([[County Tipperary]]), Ireland, the home of their friend, [[Gottfried Helnwein]]. The wedding was officiated by surrealist film director and comic book writer [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]]. It was attended by actor [[Eric Szmanda]], [[Lisa Marie Presley]], burlesque star [[Catherine D'lish|Catherine D'Lish]], artist [[Jessicka]], designer [[Betony Vernon]], producer [[Christian Hejnal]], and Manson's bandmate [[Madonna Wayne Gacy]]. The event was featured in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''.
On December 29, 2006, Von Teese filed for divorce from Manson citing "irreconcilable differences".<ref name=bbcdivorce>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6236663.stm|title=Rock star Manson set to divorce|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=January 6, 2007|accessdate=February 17, 2007}}</ref> Von Teese left their house empty-handed on Christmas Eve, and was not able to get in touch with Manson to inform him of her intention to divorce him. In an interview with ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', Von Teese stated, "I wasn't supportive of his partying or his relationship with another girl. As much as I loved him, I wasn't going to be part of that." Von Teese also stated that she gave Manson an ultimatum, and said that "it didn't work. Instead, it made me the enemy."<ref name=EducaDita/> Von Teese did not seek spousal support and expressed no interest in his assets.<ref name=bbcdivorce/> The news broke for the public and for Manson on his birthday on January 5, 2007, when he [[Service of process|was served]] the divorce papers.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=September 2011}} {{notability|date=October 2012}} }}
The '''Guru Dutt team''' is a group of people [[Guru Dutt]] created for some of his finest works. The death of Guru Dutt cut short more works. What the team created is considered to forever have left its mark on [[Cinema of India|Indian cinema]] as well as [[world cinema]].
==About== Some well-known movies the team created are ''[[Chaudhvin Ka Chand]]'', ''[[Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam]]'', ''[[Kaagaz Ke Phool]]'' and ''[[Pyaasa]]''. ''Pyaasa'' is ranked among the top 100 movies of all times by [[Time magazine]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2005/02/12/all-time-100-movies/#pyaasa-1957 |title= All-TIME 100 Movies |author=[[Richard Corliss]] and [[Richard Schickel]] |publisher=Time Entertainment |accessdate=2 Nov 2011 |date=2005-02-12}}</ref> Much of their work found critical appreciation long after these movies were made. Movies such as ''Kaagaz Ke Phool'', which was a huge commercial failure of its days, found critical and commercial success when it was re-released in the 1980s in Europe. Guru Dutt has a huge fan-following in France, Germany and Japan, where his movie festivals are held occasionally.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asian Film Series No.9 GURU DUTT Retorospective|publisher=Japan Foundation Asia Center|date=2000–2001|url=http://www.jpf.go.jp/e/culture/new/old/0101/01_03.html|accessdate=2009-04-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620144748/http://www.jpf.go.jp/e/culture/new/old/0101/01_03.html|archivedate=2009-06-20|df=}}</ref>
==The team== *Writer : [[Abrar Alvi]] *Directorial : [[Raj Khosla]], [[Abrar Alvi]] *Cinematography : [[V.K. Murthy]] *Actor(s) : [[Dev Anand]], [[Waheeda Rehman]], [[Johnny Walker (actor)|Johnny Walker]], [[Rehman (actor)|Rehman]] *Singer : [[Geeta Dutt]], [[Mohammad Rafi]] *Music : [[O. P. Nayyar]], [[S.D. Burman]], [[Hemant Kumar]] *Lyrics : [[Sahir Ludhianvi]], [[Kaifi Azmi]] *Editor : Y.G. Chawhan *Art Director : [[Biren Nag]] (worked as Art Director on Dutt's five films)
==Notable works== * ''[[Baazi (1951 film)|Baazi]]'' (1951) * ''[[Jaal (1952 film)|Jaal]]'' (1952) * ''[[Baaz]]'' (1953) * ''[[Aar Paar]]'' (1954) * ''[[Mr. & Mrs. '55]]'' (1955) * ''[[C.I.D. (1956 film)|C.I.D.]]'' (1956) * ''[[Pyaasa]]'' (1957) * ''[[Kaagaz Ke Phool]]'' (1959) * ''[[Chaudhvin Ka Chand]]'' (1960) * ''[[Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam]]'' (1962): [[National Film Awards]] for [[National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Hindi|Best Feature Film in Hindi]]; [[Filmfare Awards]] for [[Filmfare Award for Best Movie|Best Movie]], [[Filmfare Award for Best Director|Best Director]], [[Filmfare Award for Best Cinematographer|Best Cinematographer]], [[Filmfare Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] * ''[[Baharen Phir Bhi Aayengi]]'' (1966) - Released post death of [[Guru Dutt]]
==Post Guru Dutt's death== The magic of the team dissipated after the death of [[Guru Dutt]] when he was 39 years old.
Post his death, only a few of the members were able to achieve the critical acclaim they did as a team. Partly the reason was Guru Dutt's eye for detail. ''Pyaasa'' and ''Kaagaz Ke Phool'' are an inspiration for directors even today. The exceptions were [[Dev Anand]], [[S.D. Burman]], [[Sahir Ludhianvi]], [[Hemant Kumar]] and [[Mohammad Rafi]] who were already established when [[Guru Dutt]] entered film making. [[Waheeda Rehman]] may be debatable, however none of her future roles would give her same critical acclaim as under the team. V.K.Murthy continued work with Promod Chakravarthy but his notable work was in [[Tamas (film)|Tamas]] (1987), directed by his erstwhile assistant [[Govind Nihalani]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * ''Guru Dutt, 1925-1965: A Monograph'', by Firoze Rangoonwalla, [[National Film Archive of India]], [[Govt. of India]], 1973. * ''Guru Dutt, un grand cinéaste encore pratiquement inconnu hors de l’Inde'', by Henri Micciollo, Films sans Frontières, 1984. * ''Guru Dutt: A Life in Cinema'', by [[Nasreen Munni Kabir]], Oxford University Press, 1997, {{ISBN|0-19-564274-0}}. * ''In Black and White: Hollywood and the Melodrama of Guru Dutt'', by Darius Cooper, Seagull Books, 2005. {{ISBN|81-7046-217-7}}. * ''Yours Guru Dutt: Intimate Letters of a Great Indian Filmmaker'', by Nasreen Munni Kabir, Lustre Press, Roli Books, 2006. {{ISBN|81-7436-388-2}}. * ''Ten Years with Guru Dutt: Abrar Alvi's journey'', by Sathya Saran. 2008, Penguin, {{ISBN|0-670-08221-X}}.
[[Category:Cinema of India]] [[Category:Bollywood]]
